content:
ry 25, 2015
												EDIT: Crash bugs right now if you have texture size turned way up. The classics are working fine for me. By the way, you must download the DLC to be able to play the campaigns in the remastered edition. Issues thread: http://steamcommunity.com/app/244160/discussions/0/617328967243529430/Let me tell you something about homeworld (1+2 AND the lost game, homeworld cataclysm). Even 15+ years later, it's still the gold standard for 3D RTS. Here's a few big points:Very intuitive controls. Movement control is a simple two step, where the first sets horizontal movement, then *optionally* holding shift or click and drag for height. I've yet to see another 3D RTS which even comes close to how quickly and simply that I can give move orders in a 3D space, even though mice and monitors are 2D devices.Extremely helpful *contextual* visual indicators. When in the process of giving a move order, a lot of supporting information for movement then pops up. For example, to show how high other ship's height are above yours in the 3D battlespace, an ecliptic disc is drawn centered on your ships in the move order interface, and vertical lines are drawn from that disc to those other ships. It GREATLY aids in plotting the movement order so you can order your ships to intercept over long distances. Once the move order is given, all of this goes away so there isn't information overload.Battles actually take place in 3D space as well. Skilled players WILL use height to flank from above and below to avoid being subjected to a full broadside of guns. Fighters zoom around ships without regards to direction, attacking from multiple angles. This isn't "2.5D" as I would call it, you NEED to use height, especially with fighters.Two camera modes. One is the standard battle camera, which you spend most of your time in for orders in a small area, and a strategic camera, which is an "at a glance" of the battlespace with a LOT more information and large map wide movement. The space bar is the simple key to switch between them.In the story, you must be somewhat careful of losses (but it's not so bad that it inhibits gameplay). Every mission brings the resources, ships, and research that you have from the previous missions. You are quite literally a nomadic fleet. Resources on each map are *not* regenerative, even in multiplayer, so grab what you can! Think starcraft in terms of resources: it's plentiful, but resources will run out in a prolonged battle.The story itself: It's of loss and sacrifice, hope and victory. It's quite a roller coaster of emotion.Soundtrack: Very "spacey" feel that is well designed to suit each mission. Plus, mission 3 on HW1 had the best freaking use of a classic choir song (Agnus Dei - Adagio for strings) I've ever heard.My only regret: the source code to HW:Cataclysm is lost. There's no remastering it. It's not considered canon, but it was still fun playing as the mining faction's ship "Kun-Laan" and fighting the galactic cancer known as "The Beast".EDIT: Made a grammar mistake, fixed. Kun-Laan is the mining faction's ship, but I forgot to mention that their faction name is "Somtaaw"

content:
ber 30, 2015
												As a kid, I remember asking my father about all the different ships as he was playing the original Homeworld. As soon as the Remastered version came out, I had to buy it.Overall I'm very happy with the game. The remastered version is beautiful, and in my opinion one of the best things about it is that it has a great storyline behind it. While I understand that not everyone cares about that, for me it makes the game so much more. Homeworld offers a rather unique experience as a strategy game in a 3 dimensional enviornment which isn't really like anything else I've played.Both HW and HW2 remastered versions seem to be optimized well, as I've never had any lag or framerate issues. I can't speak for the mods, as I haven't yet felt the need to utilize any - there hasn't been any that I've seen that have caught my eye as a "must have".Some people have complained about scenarios being more or less difficult depending on how well you're doing throughout your campaign. Say you fail a mission, but you rememeber what's thrown at you and plan accordingly beforehand - the next time you start it stronger only to find there's even more enemy ships. Personally I kind of have mixed feelings about this aspect, it makes the game more unpredictible and more challenging, as you can't plan for everything the way you can with most other game's missions/scenarios.As a negative, I have encountered a couple small glitches with scenarios, such as objectives not checking off as complete even though you've finished it, therefore making the scenario impossible to finish. I also don't particularly care for HW2, the storyline and ship variants just don't do it for me. In my opinion the first game is far superior but that's simply a matter of opinion. I can't say I have anyone to try Multiplayer with but I think it would be an excellent MP game with a few friends looking to out-strategize one another.In conclusion, I recommend this game to anyone looking to try out a new type of strategy game in a 3D space enviornment, or anyone who gets their kicks out of a great back story like myself.

content:
ry 25, 2015
												Here is a full ist of the changes made from classic to remaster:http://forums.gearboxsoftware.com/t/another-ye-olde-homeworld-players-view-on-remastered/98847Homeworld is a space strategy game that redefined the RTS genre, and remains today as the only game that did it right. A deep and thrilling story (30 missions over 2 campaigns), powerful and anomalous music, and a very unique style of play. A true space opera!Even though games are nearly 15 years old now, the mechanics and gameplay don’t feel outdated. Instead, they are still unmatched by any other space RTS that have released since. The three dimensional environment requires a whole new level of thinking when it comes to strategy.Now let’s talk about the Remaster and a company that actually put effort into a remake. This was crafted with the assistance and guidance of the original creators as well as the help of a passionate fan community.Here’s a list of some of the changes:+ Significantly upgraded visuals, including high-res textures and models+ Up to 4k resolution+ Sound and music overhaul+ Upgraded cut-scenes with clean artwork and some new 3d animations+ Redesigned UI for HW1 (from HW2 which also got an update)+ Mod compatibility and workshop support+ Compatibility with newer operating systems+ Combined Multiplayer between both gamesAs you can see, they put a considerable amount of effort into this remastered version of Homeworld and that's why I totally think it’s worth the price tag, unlike any other HD remake out on Steam. You also get both of the original games with this package, which were previously hard to get ahold of, and they are even updated to be playable on modern operating systems.If you enjoyed Homeworld 1 and/or 2 in any shape or form, you should strongly consider buying this, as it really is a whole new experience! Let’s show the industry that there is still demand for strategy games like this, so that we can expect more in the future!

content:
ry 28, 2015
												Let me start by stating this: - I did not play the original games, so my review comes untainted by fandom both possitive and negative.OVERVIEW:At this time the game is best enjoyed single player. The campaign in HW1 Remastered is amazing and I expect HW2R's to be great as well. The story, cinematics, music and atmosphere all get 10/10CONTROLS:Some players have a little trouble getting used to the controls and while this is in part due to the fully 3d nature of the game I also feel it is in part down to the developers descision to keep the old control system rather than improving upon it. That said, everything works nicely and I found everythign easy to get used to. 8/10GRAPHICS:The game is simply stunning close up, ships are well detailed, docking ships looks awesome, the enviroments and FX are great. Could they be better.. Probably.. Are they good enough, definitly. 9/10MULTIPLAYER:PvP is still in beta, so it is hard to judge, but so far things seem real good. There are objectives and that is something I find very interesting as it is unheard of in other PvP games I play. AI is skilled enough for skirmish games and will give you a real run for your money, Changing tactics from game to game and really testing you. Only real issue is possibly balancing still needs to be done on some units. But hey, this is something completely new to the franchise so it was always going to take time. There is however no co-op campaign.. Something I find sorely lacking as it is my prefered game mode ussually. 7/10OVERALL:An exellent game, I highly recommed it to anyone who loves, RTS, sci-fi, or who is just looking to try something new or find a great story to be immersed in. 9/10

content:
er 16, 2015
												The first thing I noticed on playing HW:RM was how the HW2 UI and seemed to be everywhere. It was as if the whole HW1 game had been transplanted into the HW2 engine... turned out I wasn't far off. Homeworld 1Unfortunately there are a few things that bring the quality of the remaster down as a whole - players aren't able to experience HW1 with it's Ballistics physics engine intact (shots fired could be evaded or go on to hit something else), instead shots fired by ships generally always hit (some RNG seems to be involved) the selected target as in HW2. This is a large part of what made HW1 stand out from other RTSes at the time (in fact most RTSes nowadays) and made certain manoeuvres such as doing increased damage to ships when attacking them from behind, etc, possible since damage resistance was also modelled as part of this engine. As far as I can recall this was not something that was taken through to the original HW2 or the Remaster. Pretty big deal in my opinion.Formations in general are completely borked, meaning that a lot of the tactical (and at the time, genre defying) flavour of HW1 is completely absent; while I don't particularly miss the fiddly micromanagement and lack of context sensitive clicks, I do miss the extra depth of tactics that formations offered. If Gearbox ever start work on a Homeworld: Cataclysm remaster (the original HW:C = my favourite game of the series) they have to get this fixed. Good news is that a patch may be on it's way to restore formations to their intended form.Overall I still enjoyed playing through the HW1:RM campaign, and ultimately found it more "playable" than the original (especially while using a Steam Controller). Basically I found the game easier and more accessible than it used to be, which for newcomers and busy old-schoolers like me is not a bad thing. I think it's a huge shame we never got to see the original ballistics physics etc on todays capable machines however.Homeworld 2Being completely honest I originally played Homeworld 2 the least of the games in the series, however I feel that the remaster did a solid job of restoring and enhancing the game for compatibility while staying pretty faithful to the original. The remastered graphics really shine here, fleet battles are a thing of beauty. Seriously, pick a fight and soak in that goodness, JUST DO ITSince the remaster has been so good to the game I have in effect enjoyed HW2 anew - I'd basically offer this collection as an instant recommendation for fans of the original. The only issues HW2 fans might have is that the voice actors from HW1 have been used instead of the ones they may remember from HW2, as well as a few other VA changes here and there (notably Makaan).GeneralGearbox have been patching things up slowly, with various bugs and issues like bad pathfinding (crashing into asteroids) being fixed. There are still issues like formations not working properly and friendly ships merrily continuing to pour heavy firepower on ships you are boarding/salvaging to add to your fleet, amongst other things.Scoring based on faithfulness to the spirit of the originals;-GFX/FIDELITY 8Glorious hi-res Fleet battles and Furballs, gorgeously updated and retouched. The UI scales perfectly and there are sliders allowing you to adjust the scale of varying UI components manually. -AUDIO 7Remastered audio (apparently; I can't tell I'm no audiophile), original voice actors (notably Fleet Command/ Mothership from HW1) brought back and re-recorded. HW Classic sound effects are particularly dated and low-def when compared to the remaster, so good job I guess. -GAMEPLAY/MECHANICS 6In regards to HW1 the best I can say is some patching is definitely needed.HW2 on the other hand is in a good place. If Gearbox attempt a remake of Homeworld: Cataclysm, I hope they get a better handle on what made these games great in the first place.As a Remastered Collection It's a good update on the originals, however it's not perfect by a long shot. It's also a shame that some of the technical limitations that held the old games back have not really been challenged (in fact the opposite, much has been dumbed down). The unfulfilled potential is pretty crushing in my opinion.Multiplayer is also a bit hit and miss, in that Gearbox are clearly putting a lot of work into the facilitation of mp matches, but the bugs/missing mechanics are keenly apparent at higher levels of play.In any case I have to thank Gearbox for bringing back these games, and can only recommend this Collection as an essential for RTS fans, and those gamers who enjoy a good story alongside a challenge.

content:
2, 2015
												Sadly, as a HW player since the first game came out, (Back in 1999) I cannot recommend this game.  The first time I played Homeworld, I was a young boy about 8 years of age. My grandfather introduced me to the game, and whenever I go see him I will still play LAN games against him, on the same two disks that we have always played on. Now, with that being said, at 8 years of age I didn't really understand tactics or how to win, the main objective for me was to build a heavy cruiser and try bum rushing the enemy mothership, praying that my prized cruiser didn't get salvaged in the process! As I grew older and understood the game more, I enjoyed it more as I began using formations and tactics to alter the outcome of battles, some of which were against slim to none odds.   The depth and complexity of this game was really what hit the mark for me as I grew older. I played Homeworld nonstop until Homeworld 2 came out. I enjoyed playing that game as well from time to time as well, but my Homeworld life changed forever when the Complex mod came out. This mod essentially combined the tactical and strategical gameplay of HW1 with the beautiful graphics and upgraded UI of HW2. I have played this mod since it was released, all the way to 9.1 which is where it sits now.   Now fast forward to 2014, when I learned that my favorite strategy game was getting remastered. I poured over screenshots and gameplay, developer interviews and every last piece of media I could grasp my hands on. The promise was simple, updated graphics, and no changes to the original engine this game ran on. Unfortunately, this was a lie.   When I first booted up HW:R I was amazed with the beauty of the game, but felt betrayed as I continued to play on. The most important feature of early combat, even going forward to endgame combat, the formations and tactics features, do not work. This is a gamebreaking feature people, because strikecraft are worth their weight in gold at all stages of the game. The fact that you can no longer use bombers and corvettes to their full potential will ruin the game for anyone who has played this before. The developers essentially put everything HW1 onto the HW2 UI, all for the sake of being able to play Kushan VS Hiigarrian in multiplayer. While this introduces great improvements, such as better 3D movement and harvesting, the developers lied in their statement of, "Nothing but the graphics will change". The month is now June, and the Dev's haven't even made a comment of when these issues will be fixed, no issued an apology for their lie.   Also, mods will STILL not work the way they should in the classic versions of the game. I would be fine if I could still play Complex 9.1 on the classic HW2 game, knowing that the fix will come eventually and formations will be able to be used again. However on bootup the mods (and I'm talking other mods too, the star wars mod, the halo mod, etc) will crash and burn, leaving you empty handed. The dev's should have kept these engines separate, as even on multiplayer, HW2 strike craft will always slay HW1 strike craft, because the HW2 squadron formations still work.   As a man who has played thousands of hours of Homeworld, and in light of this 60% off steam sale going on currently, I strongly advise putting your hard earned dollars, euros, pesos, or whatever currency you're using into something else, unless you have never played this game before, because you may be able to enjoy it for what it currently is. If you have played even one skirmish vs cpu match on the original HW, don't even bother picking this up.**UPDATE**As of today, 9/20/2015, the game is still borken, formations are still not usable, and now mods are ceasing to work as the dev. launches half ***ed patches ever two months in order to justify a poor excuse for a "Supported" title. Folks, for your money id say buy an actual HW2 disk, so at least you can play the great mods that have been released. This, sadly, is not the Homeworld Remaster we were promised or expected it to be.

content:
, 2016
												At first, I was not pleased with this game. It was very buggy and frustrating, with numerous other issues like HUGE pathing problems, stupid ai and automation problems (Several harvesters waiting to get to a single asteroid to harvest when they're surrounded by unnoccupied other ones). However, the largest problems lay in the fact that "Homeworld 1 remastered" was essentially just homeworld 2 with homeworld 1 ships, because a lot of mechanics which gave the original tactical depth had to be removed so it could fit into homeworld 2's engine. This meant that the whole collection was a buggy, broken, imbalanced shadow of the originals.But then the June 7th update happened This update (in my experience so far) fixed everything that was wrong. It has fixed formations, ballistics, tactics, pathing (mostly), targeting priorities, balance, and all general bugs (that i've experienced so far).I can now safely say that:  Both campaigns offer an amazing narrative experience, complete with incredible music and visuals.Both campaigns provide a great challenge, as does the AI in singleplayer modeEasy to use and pick up basic mechanics, with complex ones to pick up laterTrademark 3d movement and map are very well implementedIncludes the 2 original games, fixed to run properly on modern OSs and hardware Maps allow for potentially hundreds of small fights at once which can be really intense as larger strategies take shape Gorgeous visuals and sound, which all run very well Multiplayer supports up to 8 players I think, which can lead to some titanic fights.Overall a great experience and a very solid recommendation after the update. 8.5/10

content:
2, 2015
												Let me start out by being fair and pointing out what Gearbox got right with HW:R - the ships look beautiful, it's quite obvious a lot of time and effort was spent lovingly crafting them and they feel very solid and real. The other eye candy like HDR and shadows is very welcome and really calls out to my first experiences of playing HW1 in 2000. Sounds and voice-overs are also remastered to a very high standard though some of the inflections aren't to my personal taste, but that's just me.Now then, onto the bugs and why I can't recommend HW:R in its current state. If you've read the other reviews by now you'll probably have found some pointing out the bugs with formations and strikecraft in general. I am no purist, but quite frankly I think these issues have been understated so far. Not being able to put your fighters or corvettes into formations massively affects the combat effectiveness of your strikecraft (less so for capitals). Since they refuse to maintain formation (regardless of tactics set) they will not fire en masse and you the player cannot position them precisely where you need and want them. A wall of just 9 heavy corvettes in HW1 would easily demolish a flock of enemy fighters if managed correctly. In HW1 the same force takes at least 3 times as long to complete the same engagement and you’ll probably take losses. I've seen positive reviews on here downplaying this issue which I find hugely disingenuous to say the least. I'm going to have to make a video showing HW1 and HW1:R side by side to really illustrate just how much this affects the game and almost everything you do in it, it really is that fundamental.Formations aside, the path-finding for strikecraft again is quite poor. Ships like the heavy corvette with heavy forward firepower seem to insist on circling the enemy and trying broadsides to no effect, which is probably why the fights take forever to finish. Because your ships refuse to stay in formation they will also largely ignore player attack-move commands during combat (ctrl+A).Other reviewers have already pointed out the firing system changes as well, but I really have to emphasise just how much this negatively impacts the game. Basically, in HW1 your ships would fire bullets that would actually travel through space i.e. no hitscan or RNG. Since this is no longer the case your ships are at the mercy of the Random Number Generator and setting them to evasion tactics has literally no effect where as in HW1 it could vastly improve the survivability of your strikecraft.I understand a lot of these changes were implemented to allow compatibility between HW1 and HW2 to enable multiplayer which is just fine imho. However, I consider the formations and tactics issues as bugs since they severely handicap HW1 strikecraft compared to their HW2 counterparts, not to mention that it robs the player of a huge degree of tactical control.I love Homeworld, but being unable to control my strikecraft effectively reduces the whole thing to pumping out ships, sitting back and hoping for the best. The pathfinding and formations issues are major bugs and I hope to the almighty Gearbox get on top of this crap.

content:
2015
												It's a real shame that one of the better games of 2015 was originally released in 1999 and 2003, respectively. Homeworld Remastered is beautiful. The music and voice acting is still spot on. I found myself re-living all of the excitement and wonder of the original release. The only thing missing is the exclusion of Cataclysm (which in my opinion is the better of the three games). Let's hope that Gearbox can find the missing(?) source code for Cataclysm and give us the missing chapter of the saga. If you like Real-Time Strategy, well crafted stories and truly challenging gameplay (your tank rush will NOT work here for every mission, you're going to have to really think about what you build, capture or destroy), this blast from the past will sate that hunger. I couldn't recommend this game any higher.

content:
6, 2015
												We all know what made Homeworld great. We all know Gearbox made a visually stunning remaster. What needs to be said now is what Gearbox did to make the remaster a disappointment. While the following things may sound petty, they fundamentally change how the game is played and the emotional tenor of the story:-removing formations-removing stances-removing fuel for strike craft-reworking repair mechanics (repairing is now not feasible in combat, it's more meant for between battles)-making diffculty scaling much more aggressive-replacing the ballistic simulation for random number generation combatHomeworld was always a story of disempowerment. Of overcoming long odds at the brink of genocide. You were perenially starved for resources, and forced to be extremely careful when shepherding your tiny little fleet. Put your craft into evasive mode and they'll live longer. Put them into aggressive mode and they'll kill faster. Use your support craft to keep expensive ships alive from mission to mission. Use the almost Napoleonic wall formation to concentrate firepower, but don't try complex maneuvers with it. The level of care you had to put into your fleet assets, great and small, contributed a lot to the overall feel of the game.Now, stances have been removed. Formations have no effect, and fall apart the moment your ships enter combat. Fuel for strike craft has been removed. Support ships are now so unwieldy and take so long to engage that they are only useful outside of combat. Individually these changes wouldn't be so bad, but taken together they rob Homeworld's story of it's gravitas, and it's gameplay of almost all its depth.It's hard to care about your fleet because your ships are now throwaway items, and honestly there isn't much for you to do with them other than throw them at the enemy fleet and designate targets. What was once a game of tactics and risk management has been reduced to a laser light show. Pretty, but ultimately there isn't much for you to do but sit back and watch.If you want a pretty game with all the familiar sights and sounds from the Homeworld we played back in 1999, then this fits the bill. If you want a game that captures either the spirit or the tactical depth of the original, then sadly you should look somewhere else.

You guys made a masterpiece into an even better masterpieceOver 9000/10

												Beyond incomplete. The Homeworld 1 "remaster" has removed :- Fuel Mechanics- Ballistic Damage Model- Formations- Tactics (Defensive/Agressive modes for vessels) The above are not "bugs" because they are features that were crucial to Homeworld 1 which have just been completely left out. Bugs include :- Functional Resource Harvesters (Often do nothing, bump into things forever etc)- Function Salvage Mechanics (You now must individually select salvage targets from large groups of targets)- Functional navigation (Often ships just collide and do nothing forever)- Numerous bugs in missions. Crashes etc. Many players can't get past mission 3 because it never loads. Homeworld 2 Remastered is much more functional but still experiences many of the above bugs. Homeworld 1 Classic. Chris Faylor said in an interview : "We had to make sure that the classics were out there no matter what, as untouched as they could possibly be for the sake of history."They removed multiplayer LAN from the Classic - not the Remastered - version. Homeworld Multiplayer Beta? Don't get me started. - Massive Balance issues - chronic disconnects- no re-joining mechanics to games - CHRONIC DISCONNECTS

content:
2, 2015
												Such a shame... What I though was going to be a true-to-original remaster, was too far off to keep playing. Being a fan of HW2, and reading the reviews and complaints of HW1 carefully, I thought I would pick it up on sale. Playing the first two HW1 missions, I saw what some folks were talking about in the way that GB had changed the fighter behaviors, and other details. I also some improvements they had carried over from 2 such as being able to select units from the space map. Being a fan of 2 I thought that this was ok since I had always seen fighters as being OP in the original. I once beat the game with NOTHING BUT fighters and bombers.The deal breaker for me came when I started the third mission. I had built 6 salvage corvettes in anticipation of "stealing" the coming frigates and using them against the enemy as I had 15 years ago. To my horror, as each frigate was captured, nothing came back out. I was like "where the hell are my frigates?!". Then I noticed that my RUs had grown substantially. I quit the game right then and started reading more into the forums and saw that this was now part of the game. Then I started looking in the Workshop to see if anyone had made a mod to fix this, and sadly there was no fix. Salvaging was one of my favorite parts of HW1. I don’t understand why someone would take a classic that was so well received and decide to cut it up as much as GB did, and describe it as being true to the original. Remasters are a common thing in the music industry. Old master tracks are taken back to the studio and are mixed down again on new hardware to bring the sound quality up to par with current music quality and to fix any “noise” that may have been in the original to clean it up. Imagine if you went to the store and bought the remastered version of your favorite band's album, only to find that someone else is playing guitar, and your favorite songs from the original are missing even though the album cover makes no mention of it? Its a beautiful game with great sound and gameplay, but a remaster of the original it’s not. Maybe one day GB will get their ♥♥♥♥ together and put the game back like I should have been in the first place. Watch the video that Bobamelius has posted in his review carefully if you are thinking of getting HWRM. Hell, watch it two or three times and know what you are buying. Thanks to Steam's new refund policy I'm on to the next game!

number of helpful: 112 of 153 people (73%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
2, 2015
												Via reddit: http://www.reddit.com/r/Games/comments/2xcwdl/homeworld_remastered_the_good_the_bad_and_the_ugly/I've spent about 8 hours with Homeworld remastered re-living one of the best game experiences I can remember, and have to say that there are ups and downs to the remastered version.The good:    The graphics are beautiful yet look like I remember them. That is to say Gearbox has done a great job of updating the graphics so that the game looks as it should through my rose tinted glasses of fond memories :)    They stripped out some mechanics that were a real pain in the original, specifically fuel for fighters.The Bad:    Stripping out some of those features had unintended consequences. For example, strike craft used to automatically fly home to refuel from time to time and would automatically be repaired and re-armed. Now since they don't have fuel they don't return to base on their own and die very easily left to their own devices.    Gearbox removed the 'aggressive' and 'evasive' posture from the original which used to be very handy for keeping your ships alive longer. In the original game you could re-position your forces, withdraw, or wait for reinforcements without taking crippling losses, but now these situations lead to crippling losses.    Formations don't seem to be working right... you can put your ships in formation but they break that formation if so much as an enemy fighter shows up.    Automatic harvesting was added but works inconsistently. This was a Homeworld 2 feature meant to be a time saver so you could hyperspace out when the mission was done instead of waiting for 40 minutes for your harvesters to finish gathering resources. It's broken though so it seems to harvest random amounts and not everything on the map.    Another homeworld 2 feature they seem to have dabbled with is dynamic difficulty, which I personally hate. It basically punishes you for playing smart on prior missions and removes most of the incentive to do a good job rather than just scrape by. They should have left it out or put in a difficulty level selection.The Ugly:    Frequent crashes to desktop even with updated drivers and directX. There are some bugs in the graphical portion.    Myriad scripting errors including...    Some missions can't be completed about 1/3 of the time. For example the mission diamond shoals has a nasty bug where after you clear the minefield the bentusi may or may not show up making the mission un-finish-able. As if this wasn't bad enough the bug also exists in the automatically made quicksave at the start of the mission, so if you get stung by this error you have to reload in the previous mission.    In the previous mission there's a scripted event where fleet command tells you about enemy defender ships and how you should research your own... in my game the research option didn't show up, so I literally cannot build this type of ship for the rest of the game.    On later missions similar bugs appear where you finish all the objectives but just can't finish the mission.    Some AI seems to have been lobotomized in transition. The garden of kadesh used to be very tough, but now most of the enemy ships don't do anything...

ry 26, 2015
												Homeworld is sacred. Homeworld is art. Homeworld is one of the greatest PC games of all time.I for one, embraced this remaster and embraced the return of the the great art that is Homeworld.That said, this remaster might not appeal to the hardest of the hard core HW1 players.If you prefer HW2, then by all means, get this now.If you're extremely picky about all the HW1 mechanics, there's a lot of HW2-ism that clashes with it. Formations, tactics and certain game mechanics (and bugs at this point) are making it very obvious that it's a HW1 port in HW2 engine. I've never been a huge multiplayer player in HW1, but I'm a huge single player fan. I've played a few LAN games with my brother and friends, loved it, but I was never a master player in the "Internet ladder" sense.That said, I'm a much much bigger fan of HW1 (never even finished HW2 completely), and played it a LOT back in the days. The remaster didn't kill any of the experience for me. Sure, I prefer a lot of the stuff from the vanilla HW, and would love to see it return, but I realize, not all of it is possible by patching the game. And I'm ok with it. Now I can't wait to play through HW2 campaign too, and try out the MP.So yes I do recommend this to die hard fans of both Homeworld 1 & 2, but only if you're not extremely picky about old HW1 mechanics and are willing to play through this game with slightly different approach.If you've never played HW games before, get it now!Oh, and you get both old classics along, so this to me, is a great deal. Thumbs up!

content:
11, 2015
												Can some people have fun with this game? Yes. Can I, personally, recommend this? No, sorry. You licked my lollipop, rewrapped it, and then sold it back to me; what did you expect.Full disclosure: I own the original disc versions of HW1, HWC, and HW2, and have been a big fan of at least the first two.I played the crap out of Homeworld 1 and Cataclysm for years, both the campaigns and multiplayer. I rediscovered them all over again several times, when unpacking boxes or reinstalling a new PC. They are at the top of my all-time favourite games.HW2: I think I finished the campaign once, and not in one go. It just felt like a step back from the previous ones, for several reasons. Still, it entertained me for a good while and in some way stilled my hunger for a continuation of the HW1/HWC line.Was I excited about a remaster? Absolutely; I like shiny new graphics and better sounds, and I looked forward to having the games install and work 'out of the box' on current day OS. But for me, that was literally all they needed to do. Because functionally, HW1/HWC already worked exactly as they were.For me, they could not have done this remaster any more wrong if they'd tried:* They picked the wrong engine. If it was at all true that they could not do a remaster of both with each their own engine, I would've picked HW1 over HW2 every day and twice on sunday, From my perspective, it would've made their job easier: just dumb down the HW2 races/campaign to ignore the superior HW1 formations and strafing and ballistics, et voilá, HW2 on HW1 engine. Besides, this argument reeks: they went to the trouble of completely redoing/reinventing the HW1 campaign and ships and balance on a HW2 engine... and that was somehow less effort than simply keeping those parts of the existing source code unchanged? Hogwash.* They picked the wrong UI. Yes, it took a few moments and maybe a peek at the manual to figure out how to call up the HW1 UI, but the almost entire absence of it made Space(tm) feel Real(tm). I agree that the research/build/launch dialogs would have benefited from an overlay implementation, but functionally they worked much better than HW2.* They picked the wrong camera movement. In HW1, when rotating the camera with right mouse click, the pivot point is the ship or object you focused on. This feels utterly natural, because that is what focus means: maintain your view on your point of interest while rotating to get an overview of all that surrounds it. In HW2, the camera instead pivots on itself. Aside from breaking immersion (wait a minute, am I part of this story, or am I filming it?), it does not maintain focus on what you told it to. Homeworld is not an FPS!* They killed the AI in so many ways. Strikegroups break formation the moment they start moving, or never form up the way it was intended in the first place (sphere guard, anyone?), broken pathing makes ships get stuck in places, ships forget halfway what they were ordered to do and need to be reissued so they don't either stop in the middle of nowhere or decide to do some suicide move on their own.* The remastered graphics and sounds, while pretty and certainly a significant step up from the originals, end up being underwhelming when compared to community mods like Complex which have been available for years.And as if messing up the Remastered versions wasn't enough:* They messed with the 'Classics'. Yes, they included a 'Classic' version that supposedly kept the original experience intact for those who may not like all the changes in Remastered. Which I would've been happy with, except... they kept the bugs/shortcomings intact (no widescreen/high resolution support unless hacked through registry), but they messed with things that should and could have been left alone (load/save no longer compatible with original savegames; LAN multiplayer removed; D3D/sw rendering removed).Why? Especially that last one: it was already becoming difficult to make the originals work on current hardware and OS... and they go and remove compatibility options that existed in the originals! What exactly is the point of including HW2C then? It's not as pretty as HW2R, *and* it's now almost as bad about backwards compatibility. Pointless. If you need a lighter version to run on somewhat lesser hardware, just run HW2R with all graphics options turned to minimum. (except now, since they removed the other pre-existing rendering options, it's OpenGL 3.3 or nothing. Sucks to be you if you don't have updated compatible drivers).I played a few missions into HW1R before I got too irritated and went back to HW1C. Two missions short of the end of that campaign, they then published a patch for the Remastered version that somehow managed to break load/save in HW1C, making it freeze and crash on loading savegames created just days/hours before.  So I ended up playing halfway through the campaign on my original disc versions before even feeling like trying again.Did I miss the remastered resources while playing HW1C / HW1 original? Quite honestly, not in the least. They are a shiny bonus, indisputably, but simply have no bearing on the masterpiece that was and still is HW1.In the end, I just feel duped for letting my nostalgia win and buying into the pre-order. This collection does not deliver: it removed what was good and added new gripes, in exchange of some shiny graphics and rerecorded sounds. On top of things, where my original dics versions came with the soundtracks included, now they want additional cash just for the soundtracks (which are not even complete btw, something about licensing quarrels).I noticed some people keep arguing that it's 'only' been days/weeks since release, that we cannot expect everything to work right yet, that we should allow them to get feedback and patch things. I regard this a non-argument.Under normal circumstances, with a production from scratch, that argument already makes me grit my teeth. Software/gaming has to be the only industry where consumers not just accept, but even *defend* incomplete and bugged-to-hell product releases. This should not be acceptable, and if consumer rights were anywhere near any other industry, we'd all be eligible for a refund.BUT THIS IS NOT A NEW RELEASE!! They had full access to the original sources. Again: they started with full access to the original source code. They even had the original developers assist them! And even with all that, their release is broken through bugs or intention. They do not get to claim 'needing time to fix inevitable issues' when those issues are in most cases clearly caused by meddling with code that did not need to be touched to begin with.Whether some people may like HW1/HW2 Remastered the way they are is frankly irrelevant to me. I'm sure there's plenty of people that feel Mona Lisa's smile could use a little retouching. It still does not make it right to put a marker to the master piece. If the original developers felt like they didn't get to make their 'definitive' version of Homeworld before, they could've saved that for Homeworld 3, or more likely, a future DLC for Homeworld Remastered.End verdict: A lot of money for shiny graphics and rerecorded sounds packaged with broken functionality, which makes at least this vet go back to the originals.P.S.: for the ones asking about Steam showing my play time increasing - that is me trying out the dozens of mods already coming out trying to restore what Classic/Remastered changed from the originals. Just let that sink in: the community, with limited tools and gimped access to game data, making right what the developers couldn't do with full access to everything.

												What is there to say about this game?It's 16 years old, putting some fancy graphics on it literally makes every Space RTS of the past decade run in fear.The Music is top notch, screw your Dubstep and Hipster music, this game has Classic music and you will love it to death (and one rock song in the credits).The Story is intriguing and atmospheric, if you are one for the story part of a game, this will be your Mousse au Chocolat on cheesecake with a cherry on top.The Gameplay is easy to understand, at first it might seem overwhelming, but the learning curve is not too steep.The Graphic has improved, thanks to the Remaster, to a very to-date level with many options to fine tune it to your liking.What you get for 30€ are one of the best RTS (And for me THE best Space RTS) games ever made, plus it's sequel, in a fancy new look while keeping everything that made Homeworld the outstanding game that attracted a huge fanbase 16 years ago, and if you don't want to play the updated graphics, you also get the original classic versions as well!10/10 If you are a Homeworld fan this is a must buy!

8, 2015
												I'll start with the obvious: yes, the remastered graphics and sound are absolutely beautiful. That alone almost makes this a worthy buy. HOWEVER...This is Homeworld 1 re-created in the Homeworld 2 engine, which is actually a major downgrade. There are major differences that make this bad.- They removed the ballistics system. Ship attacks are all random-number generator rolls now.- They removed the ship tactics. You can't select aggressive or evasive tactics anymore.- Formations still exist, but they don't actually work.- Unit pathfinding is pathetic. Ships can get stuck easily.Aside from the 3-dimensional game space, these were the things that made the game unique and exceptional. Without them, Homeworld 1 loses its most important elements, and you end up micromanaging your units instead of leveraging the brilliant ship formation and tactics system.

												Hands down, one of the Best RTS Games of All Time.And now that it finally has the ability to not only work properly on Modern Day OS'es, ALONG WITH Updated Gameplay, Remastered Graphics, Improved Multiplayer, etc.... AND the fact that I get both the Classic Versions AND the Remastered Versions of both HW1 & HW2 in one?! Why the hell ANY FAN of this game in the past would turn this game away is just beyond my ♥♥♥♥!The fact that we can now fight each other in Multiplayer with all 4 races from both the 1st and 2nd Homeworld Games is just absolutely fantastic. That was something I always wanted to do in the past, and now I can do so without mods! How could I possibly say "No" to this game?!However, there are some things to note. A lot of people have been complaining about some of the balance changes specifically regarding Frigates and Capital Ships. Primarily the fact that their HP has been DRASTICALLY nerfed since the originals. And unfortunately, I completely agree. I find this nerf to be very unnecessary and kinda makes capital ships and frigates to be a lot less useful as they used to be. Thankfully, however, there is a fix for this in the workshop.There is a mod called "Remastered Re-Balanced" that is available to get in the Steam Workshop that fixes nearly Every Single Problem I have with the Rebalancing Changes that Gearbox made. If you wanna play this game and fix all the problems that are present with the Remastered Versions with Frigates and Captial Ships, along with many other things as well, I would STRONGLY RECOMMEND getting that mod. It will make your game 10 times better. You have my assurance on that one.Now with that said, some people are gonna be confused as to why Homeworld: Cataclysm was not included in the Remastered Collection. The reason behind this is because the Original Source Code of Homeworld Cataclysm is currently Missing. The original game developers of Cataclysm are long gone now. But Gearbox has said if anyone has any leads to where that Source Code may be, to report it to them immediately. But honesttly, it could also be said that it might just be easier to re-do the whole game from scratch at this point. But regardless, there's already a mod in the Workshop right now that allows you to play as the Somtaaw in HW2 Remastered. So that's definitely a start. But I still would have loved to play as The Beast again. Hopefully someone will make a mod of that too if Gearbox doesn't remaster Cataclysm.But the bottom line here is this:This Game is a MASTERPIECE. If you love Sci-Fi RTS Games and if you love things like Star Wars, Star Trek, Battlestar Galactica, Babylon 5, Mobile Suit Gundam, etc.... This game will MOST DEFINITELY be something to pick up........What, are you still reading this? GO! Buy this game right now! Stop reading and do it! It's worth every single penny in your wallet that you spend on it! It's a Legendary Spart RTS, for Christ Sake! GO! NOW!

content:
1, 2015
												Take yourself back to a simpler time. A happier time. A time when PDAs were cool, people wore really high jeans, and when Homeworld was released.That's right. Take yourself back to September of 1999. I was 7.This was a time when strategy games were designed to be pursued and beaten over the course of weeks or months, a time when game designers weren't afraid to kick you in the balls and tell you that you were terrible at their game, and a time when thousands of Homeworld players ripped their hair out after spending hours harvesting resources only to have their fleet obliterated in one short battle.As a 7-year-old, I did not possess the mental faculties to fully understand the majestic space banana or its purpose as the salvation of a species. I was completely unable to tactically order my fleets through the three dimensional battlefield.  As such, I had no hope of navigating the campaign, but what I could do was build hundreds of space fighters, frigates, capital ships, and carriers, and watch in awe as an epic battle between two armadas unfolded before my very eyes in all its polygonal glory. Many happy hours were spent watching interceptors swerve around capital ships while my ion frigates bombarded them from afar.Oh that magic nostalgia feeling. How welcome it is. Homeworld remastered has taken the elegant design of the original game (something I'm now more equipped to appreciate) and made it more palatable with gorgeous visuals and streamlined interfaces while keeping the incredible atmosphere, mystery, and ♥♥♥-poundingly difficult strategy that we all know and love. A million thumbs up.

content:
ry 28, 2015
												7/10Essentially Homeworld 1 skins in the Homeworld 2 engine.  If you've never played the original Homeworld, the remastered version is the game for you.  If you have, however, you'll come to realize that Homeworld 2 was a step back in terms of strategy and micromanagement of your fleet.  The formations in the original Homeworld, for example, allowed ships to move in an ACTUAL formation.  In Homeworld 2, these formations break apart as soon as you move in any direction besides forward.  Another thing is ship intelligence.  In the original Homeworld, heavy/multigun corvettes tended to strafe around the target, with their fronts facing the target.  This allowed maximum damage since no gun was obstructed by another.  In Homeworld 2, the "strafe" of corvettes is just a circular movment around the target, no fronts facing at all.  This meant that damage output is reduced, since the guns on the opposite sides do nothing.  Oh, and difficulty scaling.  Seriously, ♥♥♥♥ difficuly scaling (Sea of lost souls mission on remastered...like no..just kill yourself).  These three things are the most disappointing aspects of the remastered, in my opinion.  There are a bunch of others I didn't cover but I'm sure somebody has in the reviews of this collection.  All in all, this collection is really just a nostalgic trip down memory lane.  Graphics are top notch and so is the UI.  The original versions of the games are also included (which is freaking awesome).  Get this collection even if you have or haven't played this game.  For the old vets, it's a nostalgic trip and for the new players, its an experience you don't want to miss.

This collection include both HW1 and HW2 classic, and their remastered version, and also a multiplayer via Steam or LAN.  Masterpiece remake with modern graphic technology makes it legendary once again!+Complete collection include Classic HW1/HW2 and Remastered HW1/HW2 and Multiplayer+Awesome modern graphic support even up to 5k resolution+Not only graphic, but also the audio is HD+Original great stories in HW1 and HW2 come back with gorgeous graphic+Mods on Steam Workshop support with both Classic and Remastered version+Multiplayer via Steam is easy to find and join or host the network game+Devs read Steam Discussion and user feedback*No new ship or tech tree or story.  All the same system with modern graphic and audio and UI-No "YES"-x1 UI scale is too small and x2 is too big.  We need x1.5 in 1920x1080-Badge browser in Edit Profile has alignment error.  All badges display in single vertical column-Mod toolkit is just an uploaderThe remake graphic is just so awesome so that all the details are so vivid.  If you were Homeworld old player back in 1999, you must come back to join the splendid battle once again and see your favorite ships in HD.  If you are new to Homeworld, this is the best 3D RTS from 1999 till now you should try!經典的全3D RTS大作，Homeworld在1999年發行時重新定義了3D RTS的遊戲，直到現在都仍然是個傳奇，這個Collection包含了經典一二代、以及重製一二代、以及一個透過Steam或區網的多人連線模式。經典作品以現代繪圖技術重製，讓傳奇再次回歸！+完整的大包，包含一二代經典版與重製版以及多人連線模式+絕讚的現代繪圖技術，解析度支援到5k+除了畫質以外，所有音效也是高音質+一二代原作經典劇情以高畫質完整重現+工作坊的模組能支援經典或重製版+透過Steam多人連線機制可以簡單快速的尋找、加入或創立多人遊戲+開發團對持續關心Steam討論區與玩家意見*沒有新的船艦、科技樹或故事，除了畫質、音質與介面升級以外其餘基本系統都跟舊版相同-沒有"YES"-x1介面太小，x2介面太大，在1920x1080解析度下需要x1.5會比較適合-在修改個人檔案的頁面，徽章排列有bug，呈現一直行排列佔空間-官方提供的Mod toolkit只是一個上傳器而已重製版的畫質實在是非常漂亮，所有的細節都非常精緻。如果你是1999年的Homeworld老玩家，你一定要回來再次參加浩大的戰鬥，並看看你的愛船以高畫質重現。如果你是新來的玩家，那這款從1999年到現在都是最棒的3D RTS，你一定要試試看！PTT Steam板 中文心得https://www.ptt.cc/bbs/Steam/M.1425322402.A.2B6.html

ber 12, 2016
												I was bored and waiting for a train one day in August and saw an issue of PC Gamer, a "100 Greatest PC Games" special issue. Homeworld Remastered was at spot number 62. I tend to suck at RTS but I added it to my wishlist for later. I impulsively bought it the other day, after games higher in PC Gamer's list didn't quite click with me, and it's shaping up to be one of my best purchases on Steam ever.You play as a race of peoples whose culture and history have been erased, but have managed to preserve a map to their ancestral homeworld. Your attempts to reach the homeworld are resisted by an Empire, with whom your people have had contact thousands of years prior. The story is wonderfully enigmatic, and poignant, and thrilling. There's a curious religious element several stages in, which I also won't spoil. Mission objectives are varied, with unexpected twists and emergency changes of plan when things often go awry. The interfaces are beautiful and clean, and the mechanics of the game are fairly easy to pick up, with a short tutorial that should cover everything you need to know.So yeah.TL;DR -- Doesn't matter if you're not a strategy or RTS buff. Unless you don't like space and are allergic to fun buy this now. P.S. And if you're curious how this game looked in 1999, you have the option to play each of the games in classic mode.P.P.S. Damn Homeworld II is way harder than Homeworld I ;_;

content:
er 26, 2016
												Singleplayer review Homeworld, first released in 1999 and developed by Relic Entertainment, is a science fiction real-time strategy game. This was their first breakout success and was met with critical acclaim and successful sales, which lead to a sequel. In 2015, Gearbox decided it was time Homeworld became accessible to a modern audience. Working with most of the original development team, they painstakingly remastered the two original games. Their time and effort really paid off with this beautiful and lovingly crafted remake.PlotFor a Space RTS one would expect the story to be a bit one-note. Thankfully that isn’t the case with Homeworld, as the story is one of almost movie quality. It begins 100 years in the past. The world you live on is a harsh desert world, with its people split into warring tribes and factions. One day a crashed spaceship is discovered in the desert. Inside this spaceship, a stone table is found. The only two things on it are a map to a planet and the word "Hiigara" — home. The discovery of this tablet proves that the people are not as alone in the galaxy as they thought and this unites the factions. Jump forward 100 years and you start the game at the grand launch of the "Mothership". Thanks to what was learned from the crashed spaceship, this is the first ship capable of traveling at hyperspeed. What starts of as a routine test of the Mothership’s hyperspeed engine quickly turns into an ambush by an unknown enemy. To say any more about the story would lessen the impact it would have for new players. So the main mission is to overcome many perils and to guide your people to the lost homeworld of "Hiligara"GameplayHomeworld doesn't really break the RTS mold, as the main focus is still on gathering resources, building a fleet and using it to destroy enemy ships to complete objectives. The one thing Homeworld does differently is the movement of ships. Because Homeworld is set in space, ships can move not only forwards, backwards, left and right, but can also travel upwards and downwards. This adds a whole extra dimension to fighting. You are not limited to a flat plain, but can use height for tactical advantage or even retreat to escape enemies. With this you have two view modes in which to control your fleet: Standard mode, which is the standard view mode with which you can select ships or watch battles or Tactical mode, which gives you extra details on where your ships are heading and gives a much easier representation and understanding on what height your ships are at compared to enemy ships. This mode is mainly used for precise movement of ships through the battlefield.Level and game designThe campaign for Homeworld 1 is broken up into 16 levels, with Homeworld 2 being structured very much the same way. The player starts out with an objective and then must accomplish this objective before they can proceed to the next. In between each level is a voice acted black and white animated cutscene, which acts as narrative progression. While common today, it was a very unique way of telling a story back in the days before 3D rendered cutscenes. The look and feel of the game goes without saying. Anyone, who has played a Relic RTS in the past, can expect the same smooth and responsive unit control and well detailed vehicle models. The game is full of beautiful backdrops of various parts of space, from moons to bright and vibrant suns, they really set the mood and feel of the game. To also accompany that is the amazing soundtrack that just helps add so much atmosphere and wonder to the whole story. The use of orchestral instruments and choirs during the beginning of the game just gives such a sense wonder and vastness, which fits the fact that your people have to travel the vast void of space in search of a home. But as the game goes on the tranquil music turns to strange tense hunting music, drums and alarms to really put you on your toes, knowing that the enemy is everywhere trying to hunt you down. Sci Fis of the time, such as Battlestar Galactica, obviously had a huge influence over the soundtrack.If any complaints have to be made, then it can be said that the movement system can be a bit tricky. Due to the 3D movement of ships, it can take a while to understand and get used to at first, as it isn’t very intuitive. That being said, there's a tutorial at the beginning of the game. Another minor gripe is the steep difficulty curve. Some missions are a walk in the park with others being extremely tough. It does help to make the levels very rewarding to beat though.In conclusion, Homeworld Remastered is a very solid and complete package. This is a perfect example of what a remaster should be, not only including the original unedited non-remastered versions of the games, but also reworking everything from adding a new game engine, re-recording voice lines by the original voice actors and a fully remastered score. Relic has outdone themselves by putting so much love and care into this re-telling of an amazing story. With two games and multiplayer modes for each, Homeworld is sure to keep players occupied for hours on end!

												On the positive side: The game is very, very pretty when it works correctly, and it includes the complete untouched originals as a bonus, except they actually work correctly on Windows 7 64-bit from what I'm seeing. Homeworld remains one of the greatest PC games ever made. The uniqueness and originality of Relic's game is still unmatched and it required very little touch-up work to remain breathtakingly beautiful.On the negative side: Homeworld Remastered has many bugs which you will discover rapidly. I certainly did, in my first few minutes of play. The tutorials do not work; the voice instruction speeds by without waiting for you to hit 'ok' to continue, and hitting 'ok' will in fact skip a section of voice. The tutorial in HW1R is in fact for HW2, not HW1; it includes HW2's ships. Achievements do not work; they only unlock when you leave the game, and even then it seems to be a fifty-fifty tossup whether you get ones that you earned in your last play session. The game is highly unstable; I had to uninstall and reinstall it multiple times due to the game entering a state of crashing whenever you did anything at the launcher, and I'm still not sure what's causing the instability. If you have any sort of desktop overlay software running, for example MSI Overdrive, AMD Raptr, Stardock's Windowblinds and Deskscapes, or even apparently the steam overlay(!) you will suffer graphical glitches including transparent ships, broken UI effects and broken HDR effects.I'm keeping the game because I like having a version of HW classic that works on my machine. I wish the remastered edition worked equally as well. Hopefully in the future patches will fix this, at which point I will change my opinion to positive.

												Please watch this critical review video before buying: 


YouTube™ Video:

My review. First of all I want to start off with the positives. The game has been beautifully remastered. The graphics are unimaginably improved from the original 1999 release and runs smoothly even on the highest graphics settings. Ive heard though some people have been getting black screens on startup. It is the first release of the remastered collection so some problems like that are expected.Now I have to get a bit Nit-PickyIf you are thinking this is truely Homeworld1 remastered, think again. Many parts of the gameplay have been changed from how they were in the original. For instance fighters no longer require fuel, research costs money, ship count limits have become stricter, etc. These changes are welcomed by some and detested by some. The remastered version also uses Homeworld2's UI. It is cleaner and more modern than that used by HW1 but many argue that it provides a lot of meaningless information and takes away from the more simplistic feel of the original.There are many more bugs in the game than I expected. Formations for strikecraft are completely useless as no matter what tactics you assign to your fighter squadrons they always break formation when engaging enemies. A lot of the original formations and tactics functionality has been destroyed. The AI pathfinding is pretty bizare. I formally sent my findings regarding these bugs to gearbox and they tried to assure me via E-mail that they are working hard on the issues mentioned and are trying to pop out a patch within the month. Not sure it will actually happen but I am happy about gearbox's enthusiam for improving their product.Despite the bugs and sometimes unwelcome changes I still reccomend the collection to anyone. I advise older fans of the game like me to do more research into the changes in the remastered before being completely commited. That being said the collection still includes legal no-cd versions of both original games and is alone worth the money. The remastered versions and revitalized multiplayer are welcome bonuses.= UPDATE =After a long wait formations and tactics have been returned to the game. Now it is so more like the real old thing that it is worth everything to play again. It is once again a great game and I strongly reccomend it. Now that it has proper working formations tactics and ballistics the game is so much better.

												A few years ago I began searching for a space RTS. I found a game called Homeworld. Allthough I was unable to play the game due to it not being downloadable and the region I am in. So I played other games and kept Homeworld in the back of my mind. Last week when i noticed it was coming to steam I jumped all over it. The maps are too small and really result in quick deathmathes in skirmishes. All the while I am still loving the game I just needed it to offer more freedom. So I went looking for the perfect mod. I found Complex mod. Its exactly what I wass looking for and in my opinion makes the game what it should be and to me the best space game out there. Complex has a skirmish map that is 60000 km. Its basiclly a galaxy for you to skirimsh on. But its so big you have to use hyper space to travel long distances making it hard to be found and easy to disapear. If you like space, rts games, and you feel u havnt found that game yet. This game migh just do for you what it has done for me. I suggest using complex mod. It can only be used with classis HW2 for now, but you will not regret it. Remastered is great but with no mods to help me immerse myself into the galaxy, I will stick with HW2 classic for now.My Verdict:Visuals 9/10Sound 10/10Gameplay 10/10Replay Value 9/10Mods 10/109.5/10 without mods10/10 with modsThanks for reading.

content:
ry 25, 2015
												This review assumes you've already played Homeworld 1 or 2 before.tl;dr If you were hoping for a faithful and direct Homeworld 1 port - I'm sorry. You aren't getting it. This is Homeworld 2 with Homeworld 1 assets dropped in. Almost all HW1 related gameplay mechanics that made the game stand out, are gone.Pros:Upgraded graphics and UI; better multiplayer options (Relics, objectives, tech level, etc.), higher quality audio. Some under the hood changes to make HW2 mods easier to port and give modders some more tools. In the end, there's not really much to say on the pro side. We already know that both games are pretty good. Quality storyline (though the second game doesn't follow through like the first does) good art design, detailing, etc. If you've played the game before, you know all that. As such, most of this is...Cons:Most gameplay elements from Homeworld 1 have been completely stripped away to shoehorn it into Homeworld 2's engine: Ships do not stick to formation during attack runs; missile destroyers output a constant stream of missiles instead of a short high-dps alpha strike; Support frigates are essentially useless - they no longer repair larger ships, and with the removal of fuel requirements, strikecraft no longer dock and repair automatically at them; you can no longer exceed fleet limits with salvage in HW1- probably one of the most-liked defining 'bugs' of the game; multiplayer requires a 3rd-party DRM/sign-up to play; there is no way to disable mouse acceleration/smoothing or change mouse sensitivity; on multi-monitor setups panning is frustrating because the mouse isn't captured to the screen; UI elements come in four sizes: Big, really big, humongous, and jesus christ it's huge; multiplayer is in an unfinished beta state.I bought this game specifically for Homeworld 1 multiplayer - the original is no longer playable because it relied on a 3rd-party system called Gamespy. This remastered version of the game now ALSO relies on a 3rd-party system/DRM check called Shift, so who even knows how long multiplayer will be available. Certainly not nearly a decade like the original Homeworld 2.The rub is this:If you are like me, and you wanted to play Homeworld 1 like it was, in singleplayer or multiplayer; skip it. This is Homeworld 2 with Homeworld 1 ships in it, repackaged and resold. Modders have already done this with Homeworld 2. None of Homeworld 1's game mechanics made it into this "remaster".If you are only interested in Homeworld 1 or 2 with an updated coat of paint, and don't care for Homeworld 1's game mechanics, then it's worth a buy after a price drop. (As of writing, the game is nearly $40).Frankly, this game is an insult to Homeworld 1 fans. I can't say I'm surprised that the dev team took the easy way and just dropped HW1 assets into HW2 without doing anything to actually make them work - we're talking Gearbox here. I should've known better than to put money down with them at the helm.-----That said, most Homeworld fans have only played the second game, so in terms of mass appeal, this game still works. A lot of people are excited about their favourite Homeworld 2 mods - Complex, etc. being ported, and these people will likely be quite happy with the game. If you're a Homeworld 1 fan though, you got shafted.

content:
, 2016
												Homeworld Remastered was released in February of 2015. In spite of being a Homeworld fan, I decided to wait for the reviews; and I was glad that I did. While the game was not short of impressing people for its new visual enhancements + the merging of both games units and assets for a unified game, the developers neglected some very important details on the game that we all love. The formations in Homeworld Remastered were screwed up. In the Original Homeworld, people remember the fact that formations assigned to groups of units actually impacted their ability to effectively and efficiently dispose enemies. As explained in details by one of the reviewers: that whole aspect was stripped away as a different method for damage calculation was done on ship to ship combat. The problem was, individual ships didn't feel individual anymore, the formations did not chew up hostile ships like they were supposed to; and that right there frusterated me, which believe it or not: deterred me from buying this game. It was only over a year after in the fine month of June 2016, that the game developers decided to release a patch which RESTORED this crucial gameplay aspect. The formations are back and are effective again! The only complaint is you can't make larger formations (large spheres would be nice). Two hours into the game, I have been satisfied with my conclusion that the game is now fixed, and the good old mechanics have returned! Coupled with the new visuals, multiplayer support, mod support and Homeworld 1 and 2 content merge; I would say this is a rather spectacular title that is worth grabbing. The 2.0 patch really did it a good number, and even though I have my doubts about Gearbox; I am honestly surprised. If you like Space RTS games with 3-dimensional movement, formations, tactics and fleet battles; I highly recommend this game. Originally made by Relic; Homeworld was and still is a one of a kind RTS game to me. Pros:+Unit formations work.+Content merge of HW1 and HW2 for interesting battles.+Very nice visuals.+Multiplayer support.+Mod support.+Modern OS support.+Everything that made Homeworld great. Cons:-There is no way to save custom paint schemes, preview for ships allows no rotation for viewing models.Overall: This game is worth it now, kudos to a company for listening to its critics and fixing something, rather than ignoring them altogether. There may be hope for gaming.

content:
2, 2016
												Note: This review was originally written prior to the 2.0 rebalance patch.  While the 2.0 patch gets the game to much better state, the original version of Homeworld 1 still remains better playing than the Remastered version; I have to stand by my thumbs down.---Homeworld 1 is in my opinion the far better of the two games and is unfortunately not well maintained in the Remastered version.Homeworld 1 was a game of relatively slow naval battles.  There was time to plan meaningful maneuvers, and the game has a certain grace many other RTSes lack as a result.  Carefully managing the units you had was in many ways more important than simply building a large number of units or even always matching units against their appropriate counter-units in fights.Homeworld 2 was headed by a new lead designer who decided to throw out most of what made HW1 feel unique and just make a Starcraft clone.  Rock-paper-scissors balance taken to extremes; huge fleets that could be wiped out in seconds; a game won more by clicks-per-second and sheer numbers than strategy.  It lost much of its grace and was a massive disappointment for me.  On top of that, another of its problems was a very poorly implemented dynamic difficulty system that scaled the number of enemies you'd face on some missions based on your fleet size and resources at the start of the mission.  On paper it's an ok idea, but in practice it punishes you for keeping your fleet alive and wasn't well tested or balanced so that sometimes you would face an unreasonable number of enemies.Homeworld Remastered puts the first game in the second's engine, and it is unfortunately rebalanced to be more like the second - complete with poorly implemented dynamic difficulty scaling.  Version 1.0 was nearly unplayable due to the balance being so bad.  The 2.0 patch pushes balance a bit closer back to true Homeworld 1 and reigns in the unreasonable difficulty scaling, but it still doesn't feel right.  Fleets that were viable with careful management in the original game still get wiped out too quickly.  Strike craft aren't as effective as they should be.  Plus there are AI problems with the units not engaging enemies the way they should.This isn't just a matter of me wanting the game to exactly duplicate Homeworld 1 due to nostalgia goggles.  I replayed the original recently and I still think it's a better balanced, more entertaining game than the compromised version of it they crammed into the Remastered engine. It's an incredible shame because the updated graphics of the Remastered version are great. I'll grant that building essentially two Remastered versions from scratch (one based on HW1's engine and another based on HW2) would be a bit too much to ask, and I'm thankful that they included the original versions in this package.  However, given that the Remastered version is a fairly big departure from the original, it is disappointing that they couldn't then do a very bare minimum of work to make the original versions more easily playable on modern systems.  Specifically, it's always been possible to configure HW1 to run in modern widescreen resolutions but it requires a registry edit to do so - not too hard for a savvy user, but still annoying.  Would it really have been that hard for them to do minimal things like update the options menu to be able to directly select modern resolutions?

content:
ry 27, 2015
												An excellent remake of an excellent game. The games hold up extremely well, even though the games are 16 and 12 years old. The devs reworked everything from the ground up as opposed to improving some textures like in most HD remakes. I finished the first campaign and played a few skirmish games and haven't encountered any bugs. The multiplayer is still in beta at this time since they are letting all the factions across both games play against each other, and things aren't balanced yet. There is a new UI and controls, mostly revamping the HW1 controls to make them more like HW2, and getting rid of refeuling for strikecraft in HW1. Ignore people that are complaining about this because it makes HW1 10x more playable. On the down side the formations from HW1, that were crucial to using strike craft don't work in the remastered version. Hopefully this will be fixed in a patch, but if you want a faithful HW1 experience the set includes both HW1 and 2 in their original untouched forms. Also I believe the campaign has gotten easier. I can't verify if this is because the game is simply easier or because I have played so much of it over the years.HW has a slower pace, so if you prefer 5 minute multiplayer matches HW might not be fore you. The story is very good, a rarity for a RTS, also the soundtrack and art is also amazing. The HW franchise was so ahead of its time that it is still innovative more than a decade on. No space based RTS has ever come close to besting it. The modding community has been active for the past 2 years for HW2 specifically, so you can expect a lot of mods comming out shortly. I wouldn't be surpirsed if HW: Remastered won many RTS of the year awards, like it did when it came out years ago. These games are a must play if you like RTSs or space based games.

												"Homeworld Remastered Collection" is a great buy if you're looking for the definitive edition of "Homeworld 2." Unfortunately, its predecessor's campaign and gameplay leave much to be desired. I've yet to finish the remastered campaign of the original "Homeworld," but I believe I've played enough to notice the various nuances that strengthen and diminish the product.While the reconstruction of the original game in the "HW 2" engine brings some welcome additons, like panning, strike groups and better visuals, it also introduces some new problems. Instead of listing them all out ad nauseum, let me just say this: The differences in the remastered edition of "HW 1" are likely to irk a good majority of classic fans.Regardless, there is some great potential in this product, and it is still the great set of games you remember. I can see some enterprising modders fixing a lot of the issues that many players are complaining about. As of 3/2/15, I would suggest waiting several months or even a year before purchasing this game.

content:
1, 2015
												HW vet says something different, still disapointedLong post get readyI played the games when they first came out of course... im 31 and was just a young kid at the time. The game was the greatest of its time as so many have pointed out. The Ui at the time was revolutionary, and so many games have tried to reproduce it but failed.The many great points of this game is what kept many playing and playing again. And for good reason, it has stood the test of time with the greats like the starcraft/warcraft series, age of empire series, and command & conquer seriesFirst some changes that I like...Fuel for fighters (except for the fact that ai fighters never had the fuel restrictions)and thats itThe "Reboot (because it is not a remasted edition in my eyes) Edition" is a complete farce because...--There are no more tactical fleet setups- no need for interceptors now that you can build bombers- no need for assault frigates, you have access to drone frigates- no need for frigates at all cause you can build destroyersThe original game had this, if you had a fleet of assault frigates you were gonna die to a swarm of fighters. why was this changed? It is intuitavly a tactical desicion thats missing--Formations no longer matterAgain so many have said this before but so many new players do not realize why they were so integral to the game. or understand why people complain about them-a wall formation would attempt to hold that formation as they attack while retreating-an x or claw formation would hold that formation while strafing-a sphere formation would attempt to guard the strongest ships at their center while attackingAs it is now every formation devolves into chaos at the first sign of enemy contactAlso The 3d management of the map no longer matters (or exists)As stated in even the first mission of Hw 1 you can do more damage on capital ships from below, above, or behind... Without the cohesive formations we had before this is a non-factor now because once they engage its a free for allCampaign Difficulty ScalingThis was something else way ahead of its time, instead of a difficulty slider the campaign progressed based on how good you were doing... the original did this well by placing a few more corvettes or frigates in at innopportune times.The new version just slams em in there."oh you played smart and made 5 interceptors on mission 1?""im gonna destroy your world and put in 20 light corvettes before the mission starts"or"you had just a mothership? oh you must be a noob, there will be no fighters to defend the carrier on day 2 ever i dont care how many you produce there will never be defenses for me cause you are such a noob"Test this one for yourselfIt is my hope that every new player to the franchise finds this post helpful as to why those veterans of the franchise fine this game so frustrating and disapointing.I know a lot of balance changes were made for the players of hw1 and hw2 multiplayer but that should never have been done, let the players choose which game they want to play multiplayer and balance accordingly dont intermingle that bull.
