content:
ry 26, 2015
												Before I start I just want to mention that I’m structuring this review for three key groups: people who are looking at Homeworld for the first time, the Homeworld 1 veterans, and the Homworld 2 veterans. Overall, this Remaster does get my thumbs up BUT in its current state there are still PLENTY of problems that need to be addressed (and therefore mentioned). I would also ask that you ignore my “play time” because sadly on my older laptop I have not been able to get Homeworld working properly, but my brother has (for the entire night in a span of about 10 hours) generously let me play on his account. Now, let’s begin…The Homeworld Experience for the new:     Homeworld is a 3D RTS type game that is done in real time and on xyz grids that allow full 3D gameplay (in comparison to 2D xy grid games such as Starcraft or Command and Conquer). If you are a fan of RTS games, be it the two games I have mentioned or Sins of a Solar Empire, you should definitely try this game. In this game, you start off with your “mother ship” and resource collectors, and your goal is to mine resources and research new ship types, and then build those ships to make fleets and then blow up your opponent. During this process, your enemy(s) will be doing the same thing, and there are even possible side objectives or challenges that can be undertaken to gain more resources to help further your cause. In the original games, there were already hundreds of different strategies utilized in multiplayer, but with these new side objectives and challenges it allows for even further diversity.     Factions are also extremely interesting to note: you have the factions from both original games, Homeworld 1 and 2, merged together in the same multiplayer experience. They are, to my surprise, actually quite balanced in gameplay. The game has really brought out the “rock paper scissors” aspect of what this game was originally about, but now with all 4 of the factions present there is a lot to take in and know what counters what, it can be a bit of a learning curve to memorize it all. This, in turn, adds to the diversity of strategy and player style you will see done by the AI and (especially) other human players.      And let’s not forget the campaigns. Two 16 mission journeys that put you through breath taking scenarios, all about a race of Humanoids that must make the journey back to their ancient home (Homeworld 1) and then defend it (Homeworld 2). Each campaign mission isn’t your standard “here you are, go blow up that person” and offer varieties of gameplay, such as in Homeworld 1 there is a mission where you can only use strike craft to complete your objective, or you have three minutes to destroy a massive ship that will ram right into your mothership if it is not taken out. Homeworld 2 offers the same mission diversity, and even gives you unique ships to fight and use throughout the campaign.  On top of that, the research method through both campaigns makes ships limited to specific types as you unlock more and more by progressing through the campaign, which allows players to get used to every single ship type and see their strengths and weaknesses, making the campaign not only fun and interesting, but all in all can be boiled down to a giant tutorial of how every single thing in Homeworld works.     On a final note, if you ever get bored with the remastered game, I highly recommend playing Homeworld 1 Classic, it features the original UI and game mechanics such as no unit cap in games that can be very fun to experiment with.     Seriously, if you Love RTS or space games and have not picked this title up yet, I seriously recommend you do so. It isn’t perfect, but I assure you that you are not only getting what your money ‘s worth but also are going to really enjoy it!From the eyes of a Homeworld 1 Vet:     This section of the review focuses on the negative aspects and what has “survived” from the homeworld 1 game.     I think the biggest thing that irks me about the remastered Homeworld 1 is that they moved it to the Homeworld 2 user interface and model. In doing so they had to can a lot of Homeworld 1’s key features that made it stand out from its 2nd game, and now everyone I have talked to who preferred 1 over 2 has agreed with me that Homeworld 1 remastered just seems to be a decently gone mod for Homeworld 2. The following is a list of features that are not in the remastered from Homeworld 1:-Refueling: your strike craft can go anywhere infinitely without being tethered to anything, allowing them to operate in the game independently and much more of a threat to areas such as your resource operation.-Harvesting:  in the first game, your harvesters flew around the asteroid and made them shrink as they collected resources (as well as dust clouds could be harvested). Here in remastered, they must dock with the asteroid to extract resources because of HW2’s -Repair: ships have to dock with other ships to repair them. While this isn’t a change for strike craft, frigates, capital ships, and resource collectors could be repaired at a range in Homeworld 1-The unit cap can’t be turned off in Multiplayer. This takes out a big chunk of what made some of the craziest HW battles that crazy (we’re talking hundreds of strike craft per person duking it out for superiority in a 6 person game)     Also, formations are a little annoying, and if you don’t believe me, I want you to go onto Homeworld 1 classic, build 9 ships, and put them into wall formation. You’ll get a nice 3x3 2d wall of the ships in a nice and orderly fashion. Do the same in HW1 remastered and you’ll get this weird cross thing with random gaps, and adding more ships to it just seems to make the cross bigger. Tactics are also screwed up with formations, and ships in specific tactics won’t always behave the same in formations the same ways that you might remember it from the Classic game. There is a new learning curve here (or bugs) that do need some attention whether you like it or not. Ships also have a tendency to partially break formation while moving (especially sphere), and on a small side note, sphere formationing ships and telling them to guard something won’t automatically make them form a sphere around the guarded ship. Again, this creates a small learning curve for the vets.     And we will complain about it, but it’s Homeworld, and we will still play it and eventually get used to it. (more on the way)

content:
ry 26, 2015
												The Homeworld series is the prime example of a (space) RTS done right. Everything from level of detail on ships, to gameplay, to mod support, and optimization are excellent. Now, I have a terrible gaming setup, a ATI Radeon 4350 graphics card with a AMD Phenom x4 910 processor. For those of you who don't speak computer hardware, this is a low end PC from back in like 2008. A piece of junk. Homeworld 2 ran great on it, and much to my surprise, so does the remastered edition. I have yet to see any serious frame issues despite playing it on a PC that is almost worth more as scrap metal than as a trade in. Granted, this is with most of the graphical settings turned low or off, but this just goes to show that you don't even need a decent computer to run the game. But for those of you who haven't played Homeworld, here’s a little about the remastered edition of the game:Its space RTS involving 4 races with up to 8 players. Each faction gets 4 different classes of units: Fighters, Corvettes, Frigates and Capital Ships with quite a few other utility class units. There are 2 Races from Homeworld 2, and 2 from the original Homeworld. There are significant differences between both generations, which is kind of interesting, especially when you consider the fact that both games are so fundamentally different, that they basically are incompatible with each other without serious modifications. Because of this, the devs, being so considerate of the loyal fan base, even decided to throw in the original "untouched" versions of both Homeworld 1 AND Homeworld 2, which is absolutely amazing when you consider the fact that Homeworld 1 is so old that you can't even run it on most systems. All in all, if you are a Homeworld fan, this buy is a no brainer. If you aren't a Homeworld fan, you're getting 2 fully retextured, rebalanced, beautiful and tactical RTS games with their original untouched (and now playable on your PC) versions. This game is a true classic, and I can't wait to see what mods make it to the Steam Workshop!10/10, Why don't you own this game yet?

content:
ry 26, 2015
												Overall this remaster is great and definitely worth buying if you like RTS games.  I rank it my 2nd favorite RTS of all time behind the original Starcraft and its expansion.  Heres my review of it:The good:The art is amazing.  The remastered textures, sounds, music, and models are all more than I had hoped for.  The new visual effects make the game as impressive today as it was when it was first released (the HW1 graphics were amazing for when it came out in 99).  Playing through the story is as fun and enjoyable as I remember it being.  I'll be spending a lot more time playing this for the next few weeks.  I like how my capital ships stay grouped up and in formation after hyperspacing from one mission to the next, that saves a lot of time setting them up.I haven't gotten around to Homeworld 2's campaign yet, but I doubt I'll be disappointed there.  That game is still easy to pick up and play today as it was 10 years ago.  So the graphical update to it will do little but make everything better.The Bad:While the remaster is great there are many changes from HW1->HWRM.  There are a lot of core changes to gameplay when the game was translated over to the new engine, many of which affected the strength of support craft, fighters, and corvettes in negative ways.  Such as: * Fighter/corvette formations having no effect on their behavior in a fight.  Corvettes don't face their targets when circling, meaning certain types of corvettes only use half of their guns in a fight.  This hurts Kushan the most because of the way their guns are laid out.* Guard works completely differently making it impossible to form defensive corvette walls and fighter balls.* Support craft healing abilities require them to be right next to the craft they are healing, as opposed to a comfortable distance away.  Making them both slower to heal because they have to maneuver into position and less effective because they cannot respond as quickly.  It also means two support frigates cannot heal each other.  They just circle around each other trying to sniff each others butts, like a pair of dogs.* Ships have wierd accuracy issues.  Many times their shots are no where near their targets, even when their target is stationary.* You can only build 2 units at a time.  In the original you could build 2-3 of each unit type simultaneously for a total 10+ units being built at one time (3 fighters, and 2 of each of the other types).  And that isn't even counting a carrier.* Research now costs RU and having multiple research vessels does not let you research multiple technologies at once.  Previously research was free and you could designate either a single or multiple research vessels to either research multiple things at once or one or two things very quickly.* Resource collectors will sometimes completely ignore patches of resources and claim that the map is dry.* Everything is less reponsive.  I think this is due to the engine, but I every click and command was crisp and responsive from the original.  In the new engine everything just feels more floaty.  Kinda like Starcraft 1 -> Starcraft 2 responsiveness.  I don't know why this is so hard to achieve in newer games but its something I've noticed.Because of that, the game plays about 60-70% accurate to the original.The Ugly:Of the new remastered graphics I'm very impressed with the missile effects ... when zoomed in.  When zoomed out they aren't there, and you can barely tell where the missiles are by the small missile pods.  In the original you could clearly see missile trails even when fully zoomed out.  And the ending credits are missing the music from Yes, but I heard that was due to a licensing issue.  If you want to see the original credits in their glory just visit youtube.  I have crashed once, and when getting back in game it completely screwed up my hotkeys in a mission where I really needed them to work from the start.  And finally, you need a "Shift" account to play multiplayer.  Its completely pointless to make one because they then force you to link it to your steam account before you can play.  Why couldn't you just use my steam account to begin with?I definitely recommend this game, but if you don't mind old graphics for HW1 you will find the original actually plays much better than the remaster.  As for HW2 its probably a direct upgrade, since this is just a modified HW2 engine the game is running on.

content:
7, 2015
												I have played the original Homeworld & Homeworld 2 since years back and I am really happy that they made a remaster of both of the games. I recently finished the Homeworld & Homeworld 2 remastered campaign and it was absolutely brilliant. Imagine your greatest gaming moments returned to life with better graphics and smoother gameplay. The nostalgia may play a big part in why I like this game, but I'll try my best to tell you the about the remastered version and the differences between the remastered versions and classic versions.+ The three dimensional movement & combat is astonishing to look at and easy to control.+ The story is great and really gives the game an amazing atmosphere around it while you play it.+ The updated Homeworld 2 UI (which is used in both remastered version of the game) is easy to understand and use.+ They captured the emptiness of space perfectly and it really sets the mood while you are playing the game.+ The multiplayer has also been updated. You are able to play as Taiidan, Vaygr, Kushan and Hiigaran on restored maps with new bonuses and game modes that I've had loads of fun with after the campaign.+ The game is slower paced than games like Starcraft, which means, you don't have to have super fast micro managing skills to be able to play well.+ The game is easy to mod and uses steam workshop.-+ The fuel system has been removed from the remastered versions (This was a system that could be seen as annoying or just another gameplay element depending on what the player thinks. The reason that the gameplay element was removed was probably because of the annoyance of having your ships becoming completely static in the middle of combat.)- The Homeworld & Homeworld 2 races are a bit unbalanced against eachother in multiplayer (Keep in mind that the multiplayer is still development).- The Resource collecting can be a bit buggy sometimes (when recource collecters want to collect debris from shipwrecks for example)- Some cool and useful attack patterns and strategies have been changed since the both remastered versions are runing on an updated Homeworld 2 engine.Overall, this game is truly a RTS masterpiece and is, AT LEAST, a must try for those who enjoy RTS.

												I can't recommend the game in it's current state. Sure, it looks pretty but beneath it's rotten to the core.I played the original Homeworld and understand how dated the original UI is. However, I would expect an improvement in a remaster. This is quite simply a giant mess. The UI is clunky and sometimes only lists certain ships you need in sub-menus. There is no master list for all production so you constantly have to shuffle through your build orders. Overall the UI is ugly, poorly implemented and does a bad job of differentiating ship classes. It's a chore.....AI is far inferior to the originals. Mobile refineries often don't work, Tactics have been totally removed. There's plenty of glitches, odd AI behavior and random crashes 6 months in as well...Do yourself a favor and get the originals or play Sins of a Solar Empire.  Maybe they will eventually fix the game but I'm not optimistic.

												Homeworld is a great game, a great franchise that deserved this great remaster. That being said, you must note that HW1 was basically ported to HW2, so if you are a HW veteran that absolutely despised the HW2 gameplay mechanics, you might find yourself disappointed.For everyone else, including those who never played any Homeworld game, this will be no problem at all - it's mostly a matter of personal taste.Only real downside to the game at this point: The balance. I have played through the HW1 SP campaign so far and I must say that after you get the strongest type of warship available, the game does get too easy. But Gearbox has assured us that balance (esp. in Multiplayer) is not final and will be worked on. (Thus Multiplayer BETA)And if all else fails, there will certainly be mods. HW2 has a very active and ingenious modding community and the remaster has been tendered to offer good mod support. So please don't take this warning as a turnoff, because otherwise, you would be missing out on a great RTS game like no other. Definitive recommendation from me.

content:
7, 2015
												Disclaimer: last 2 day, 3 patches... I hope it's not going to stop and Gearbox fixes the game issues. Summary: Pros: Homeworld 1 Classic runs, which is great. Homeworld 2 as Remastered is great too.Homeworld 1 Remastered eliminates a HW1 limitation: enemy ships target the first ship on sight and do not change target until it destroyed or docked. (and yes, that is all)Cons: Homeworld Cataclysm - where I you? I still miss you and don't give a darn about "canon". Homeworld 1 Remasterd is Homeworld 0.8. Too many things on the scewed up/missing list. Starting with the formation, pathfinding, tactics mess, ending with that Remastered misses the iconic words: "All ships autolaunching."Gerarbox changed HW1 mid-mission animations in HW1:R. Not about making engine exhausts more glaring, but changing scene and the text.Occasional crashes, 6+ GB memory usage on HW1 Remastered on Mission 14. The long one (TL;DR):Homeworld 1 Remastered screws: - Mission timings, craft speeds, game speed, map sizes as a whole. Game is too fast and far too easy. Starting with time needed for the resource collector to fill up it's internal storage bay. I do not feel even the craft speeds proper... - I had difficulties to use special actions on multiple unit at once in HW1 remastered. - Gearbox altered the between mission animations, sound track, sound effects, noises. And some of the changes simply make no sense, like the Guidestone. - Maximum zoom in and hear the difference of the Taidan fighter craft sound. - This needs checking: but for me it seems that some sounds and effects come from the Cataclysm to the HW1:R.- HW1:R lacks formation & tactics as a whole as other reviewers said. So if Gearbox decided cripple Homeworld 1, why did not they add time compression? - HW1:R UI is an utter disappointment for me. Homeworld Classics runs 1600*900 resolution and UI is far nicer.  This is personal: some ships are nicer in the HW1 Classics than the Remastered. And this is valid for some parts of the space. HW2: Would not say too much about it. For me HW2 Classic was an utter disappointment in gameplay, story and found it "too epic". Too many things unexplained in the storyline and I'm fed up with referencing recent navy technology to spaceships (torpedo frigate - master degree in lack creativity). And meanwhile there was the Homeworld Cataclysm... Please check the videos on Youtube about HW Cataclysm. See story depth, the grimm and bloody fight against the Beast and I'm pretty sure that you will also find HW2 weightless.(Not to mention that most of the Cataclysm videos are shot on normal difficulty and using 8-10% of the game's strategic and tactical offering.)

content:
ry 8, 2016
												In 1999 I played a game that would forever impress meWhen I opened the box I was presented with a beautiful manual/lore book full of information and background for the game I was playing.It was beautifulThen I loaded the game up.I was stunned by the gorgeousness of the graphicsI marvelled at how times had come along so much that this piece of art was now in my possessionWhen I played the game the intricacies of the strategy and the challenge of keeping your fleet in one piece and seeing it grow, remembering that old ion array frigate in the last mission that you acquired in the third mission, the epic story as you fought for the right to regain your homeworld and I thought it couldn’t get any better.I was wrongA year later Cataclysm was released, a standalone expansion from the original, it used the same engine but it was altered in a way that changed the rules, following a story set 15 years after landfall on the homeworld, you follow a family of miners who uncover a dark secret and a parasitic virus and you must race to stop it. Again it expanded on the visuals, tactics and story, again I thought it could not get better, and again I was wrong…Homeworld 2 was released in 2003, and with it a rewritten engine, stunning visuals that reminded me of the opening scene from revenge of the sith, and a slightly retconned but no less epic story.100 years after reclaiming your homeworld, the old enemy have arisen under a new leader. Using the artefact of an ancient super powerful hyperspace engine, But you have one too, and there are legends of a third. To reclaim your homeworld once again, you must liberate the second core, find the third and unite the cores to end the threat once and for all. Can it get better?Yes, Homeworld remastered is all of these games (with the exception of cataclysm, which I hope they add at some point) with updated engines and even better stunning hi definition visuals. It’s an epic experience. If you have played the original and loved them, buy it. If you’re a fan of epic sci fi, buy it. If you like strategy games, buy it.Just buy it, go on click add to cart and put your money where it belongs.

												I'm still amazed on this game. I played it about 6-7 yrs ago from 1-2 and Cataclysm. At the time I was like why I never heard of this such great game before then was wishing a sequel. I enjoyed an old classic game back then. Now it's back again as remastered. Now it is far greater and better graphics but funny 'coz I forgot how to play this game when I first tried it as I have skipped the turorial. I find it hard to play as I dont understand it anymore for first time again that made me decide to quit right away. But last night I have tried to play it again by going through the tutorial so I can remember how did I enjoyed this game back then. Was 9:30PM when I started playing through and guess what, the next time I looked at the clock it's already 5:35 AM in the morning @.@ that's how did I enjoyed playing this game without noticing the time.PROS:+ Engaging Story and voice narrative+ Music is really captivating+ Detailed gameplay+ Strategic in play+ Lots of ship varieties - it's a big space fleet you're gonna create and command. I'm ENDER!+ Great graphics+ Camera focus - I just like seeing the battle upclose or following the specific group engage into battle/sction+ 3D, you can go make your ships go up, down and angled. Not just a tabletop!+ Four games in this bundle remastered collection(including the classic.)+ w/ Mod support+ w/ AchievementsCONS:- Controls can sometimes be frustrating specially when moving units going down/up y-axis or I'm just terrible with it.- Slow pace, moving from point to point can be slow other than hyper jumping some of your ships- Damn no trading cards! Zzzz..- I notice some bugs to be honest but ain't game breaking.NOTES & TIPS:- Go through the tutorial first if you don't understand how to play it at first. I know some of us just wanna get right into the action like I did but it sometimes end up terrible until you just say f** this game I'm going play cod or csgo. lolMY RATING9 / 10 - Highly Recommend if you like this type of game!

content:
11, 2015
												Note - This review is ONLY for Homeworld 1 Remastered, I haven't started playing HW2 yet.'Breathtaking'  is a word I wouldn't normally apply to an RTS, but I think it genuinely fits here.  The audiovisual presentation of Homeworld : Remastered immerses you in the vastness of space, and manages to make each stage in the empty void feel varied and colorful.  Gameplay wise, you've got a fairly difficult single player campaign that forces you to learn the ins and outs of the various spaceships so you can counter your enemies in a rock paper scissors like fashion.  It's nothing groundbreaking, but it is balanced quite well, and generally feels logical and fair.  The story this game tells is also genuinely interesting, and unique.  I have yet to finish the single player campaign but I am already curious to see where things are going and what the truth is about the various factions I have encountered thus far. So .. yeah.  I recommend this game to anyone who likes playing beautiful looking RTS,  and likes a good story.   I'm not going to compare it to the original homeworld because I never actually played HW1 ( only HW2 ).   Compared to the original HW2, the remaster of HW1 feels similar, but it's been like 10 years since I played it, so take that with a grain of salt :)Well done Gearbox!

content:
3, 2016
DO NOT PURCHASE THIS GAME!!The "Homeworld Remastered Collection" was once a great game enjoyed by many, but after recent updates provided by the developers at "Gearbox Software" and enforced by "Steam" the game has become dysfunctional.

At the time purchase this product was of an acceptable standard and retained the original value, gameplay and mechanics of the Homeworld series, however after the latest update I find the game to be completely unplayable as it has ruined my gaming experience.

Further more the developers at "Gearbox Software" refuse to offer any support in relation to this matter, simply dismissing any requests or tickets by responding with a standard template stating "We'll make sure to pass your feelings along to the team so that they are aware!"

The code that went into recent updates was sloppy and mangled in an undesirable fashion to make the game more appealing to current non-existent users as an attempt to maximize profit.


For classic Homeworld enthusiasts the developers even went as far as to change several core mechanics of the game, you can't even Research Level 2 upgrades with "Hiigaran" races any more, in affect making the "Advanced Research Module" completely useless.

The Developers went beyond a "Remastering" when they started interfering with the core mechanics and gameplay.


It's a mess with several performance and gameplay issues, a poorly scaled UI and multiple crashes.

From a gamers point of view the developers have ruined a great game that I paid good money for.

From a programmers point of view they.. Completely used up all the bug spay and broke the swatter (use your imagination).


For those of you that have heard of "Homeworld Deserts of Kharak" don't be fooled this is not Homeworld 3, this is simply yet another failure by "Gearbox software"

I do not recommend buying any games from "Gearbox Software"


Don't waste your money on this purchase, it will only bring you disappointment and frustration!

content:
3, 2015
												*Gregorian Chants fill the expanse of space as the light of a distant star filters through the red gas clouds of the local nebula*For those of you who played Homeworld or Homeworld 2...you know why you should buy this.  For those of you who have never had the priveledge...this game is still considered by many experts of the RTS genre to be the defining RTS experience.  One of the most polished, best story-driven RTS games ever made, AND the sequel.It is a space saga...an epic journey of a people to reclaim their homeworld...and then...an aeon later, to flee said homeworld before destruction rains down upon them.It is...the most beautiful RTS I have ever seen.   Even before the remaster, I would've said so.  Now...it is updated in every way one could hope for, without ANY changes to the core mechanics.  The story is the same, but the voice acting is all-new, from the same actors who voiced the original.  The graphics are modernized, and the game feels...fresh.  It feels as it should;  essentially unchanged, but better than ever before!I recommend this game to anyone who seriously wishes to give the RTS genre a genuine try.   If you don't like this, you probably won't like many other RTS games. On the other hand; If you like RTS games, this will likely be the jewel of your collection.

												If you've never played the original Homeworld game, you'll probably still love this game. However, this game deviates from the original game's style and gameplay mechanics for me to recommend it to a fan.Why I think it's a bad adaptation:1: The hit-detection has been replaced with RNG and it's annoying and doesn't feel right2: Tactics no longer affect formations- units break formation when in combat regardless of tactic3: Captial class ships too tanky and ion beams are overpowered compared to the original game- fighters used to be viable against capital-class ships, this is no longer the case.4: Selection boxes are bigger than the model, this is lazy and the original game handled it perfectlyVERDICT: Get the original from Ebay, it's better and cheaper. AND you get a physical box. Not to mention that the original boxed versions still have multiplayer (unlike classic in the remastred collection)

content:
3, 2015
												It seems unfair to write a (negative) review with just a few hours spent, but the game simply doesn't impress me. This goes for the remastered versions, I haven't tried the classics yet.+ Beautiful. Nice settings, nice backgrounds, nice ships. All good.+ Sound/music. Some people might argue that there shouldn't be any explosions or sounds in space but...not me.+ User interface. Very easy to handle, gives you all the information you need. Very intuitive.+ Real 3D space battles. This is the one aspect that I still have a lot to learn of.+ There's a limited amount of resources on each map and you carry your surplus with you to the next mission.- Each battle feels like I just mass my ships and plunge them in there. No thrill, no excitement, no fun. Maybe I'm a natural at composing fleets that'll crush all opposition, but I don't know... The missions I've played so far has just been me waiting for my fleets to destroy the enemy and retreating damaged ships for repairs. And carrying tens of thousands of resources from each map means that I can build 2-3 new fleets if I should get my fleet wiped out.In conclusion, the game looks great and feels great but just doesn't give you a proper challenge. I would recommend the game if you are unfamiliar to the genre.

												I loved the Homeworld games when I was younger, but unfortunately Gearbox ruined a lot with the remaster. Simple conviences such as hotkey repair has been removed, certain mechanics have been changed without changing actual stats so the gameplay is vastly different. I found fighters to be useless in HW1 remaster. Hop on reddit or another forum and see all the issues everyone who has played the past games has run into. Also Dynamic Difficulty is my biggest peeve. You are literally being punished for playing better. Might as well scrap your entire fleet before each mission. Visually the remaster is great, but I cannot recommend this game because of all the issues Gearbox brought in. It boggles my mind how they could make the interface and game mechanics ever LESS streamlined that the originals.EDIT 4/10/16: Devs seem to have just abandoned everything. Lots of false advertisement all around, terrible mod support. Almost everyone is having issues with getting mods to work correctly. Community might as well be dead.

content:
2, 2015
												One of the best remaster's Gearbox has made. It's beatiful graphics are breathless especially coming from a 15 year old game which back then had 16-Bit pologon graphics form to make 3D models. It's audio remade into something that you would hear nowadays on most AAA games. The soundtrack is well remade and nostalgic for veterans like me and most of the other dedicated fans and players of this franchise. The story is well told and it's lore interesting and it's antagonists really likable to go up against.There are bugs like any other game and some odd design choices which can put off some gamers. It's diffiult to control at first but you'll get the hang of it after a few plays. The A.I. is pretty smart and clever and will be a challenge for players especially in campaign. The strategies and tips used from the classics unfortunatle are obsolete in the remastered so the missions are to be unexpected as we still don't understand how the game can be played in the players favor: where in the classics there was an exploit which used right would give the player great advantage over the A.I. in the campaign. A lot of the veterans complain saying its rather dissappointing and buggy and not worked out. I beg to differ. It's a really good rts game even if its buggy at it's release and realistically speaking almost every game thats released has bugs and complications upon release but it's not so bad as other games released recently by big name companies. In due time hoipefully things will get patched up and mods worked on and created to where this game is even MORE enjoyable.Pros-Amazing graphics-Great audio remake-Aamazing OST-Story-A.I.-Interesting factions to play-Mods-CommunityCons--Formations broken-Damges done to certain crafts especially frigates bug out and become shooting dummies-Tactics broken-Some minor visual glitches here and there from time to time-Crashes after hours of continous gameplay-Pop cap(Is that really necessary to have especially since modern machines are powerful enough to hold massive fleets.)-Multiplayer in BetaOverall this is a wonderful masterpiece from an underrated game. Highly recommend this to anyone interested in space battles,rts's,tactics etc. or anyone starting out with rts games. For those new to the franchise or never heard of it. They also included the classic first to games to play on as well to compare and try out as well and it's also for the veterans who lost their copy(like me :( ) as getting ahold of a physical copy of this game is like a needle in a haystack nowadays so why hassle your time in finding a physical copy of the older two games when it's included in this digital bundle.9/10P.S.-It's a shame that Cataclysm can't be remastered(source code is missing and is unable to be found) as that was a good game as well that was part of the Homeworld franchise and that too is difficult to get ahold of a physical copy.

content:
2, 2015
												(Disclaimer: This is for those who played and loved the very first Homeworld)Update; Now there is this "General Failure" crash plaguing the remastered that prevents mods and half the vanilla game. Did some digging and this crash has been happening for almost a year with no sign of a patch..... Still a buggy mess...I love the Homeworld series. It is beautiful in story and visuals, and fantastic gameplay and mechanics in the classics.(Homeworld 1 RM review)In short:I was fanboying over the visuals and sound and was having fun until I encounted more and more bugs and poor design decisions. I got too disappointed with the quality of the game as a whole to continue playing. It is Gearbox trying to mash Homeworld 1 into Homeworld 2's engine and failed, and feels rushed.In long:Homeworld RM is a HUGE upgrade in visuals and quality (stupid sexy Taiidan Heavy Cruiser)Sounds are cleaned up and sounds so much clearer and textures are great in HD (again Taidan Heavy Cruiser, I can't get over it!). UI was also updated and now a little bit more user friendly, no longer do you need to go to a WHOLE other screen for research, construction and hanger.However, it is not without its bugs, and there are lots of bugs and poor design decisions.Formations and Stances do not work as intended (I.E. Sphere formation do not surround targets, strike craft just break formations rendering formations useless. Stances do not give appropriate buffs like increased speed for evasive and increased fire power for aggressive.)Some units are unnecessarily changed (I.E repair units must now "Dock" with their targets to repair instead of repairing from a range.)Unit A.I. isn't all that good (I.E. strike craft tend to crash into asteroids and other objects in some missions)Units lifespan seems to be significantly shortened (I.E. A whole strike group of frigates won't last five minutes against a single heavy cruiser, same for strike strike craft to frigates. Rendering smaller ships hard to use or even worth using)Sound bugs (I.E. strike craft engines won't disappear if you hear them while docking)First experience with Homeworld with steam workshop mod support and sound just ceased to exist and gameplay was barely playable.And the most game breaking bug is RANDOM DESKTOP CRASHESit seems that Gearbox was trying to mash Homeworld 1 and 2 together when them both use very different mechanics and really messed up Homeworld 1 RM. Homeworld 1 IS NOT homeworld 2.I understand this is still new and update are incoming but for right now and my opinion is subject to change to updates. Until the game is more polished up and bugs ironed out, I just can't recommend this remaster in its current state. I still perfer to play the CD versions because it is much more stable. Even though this is just Homeworld 1 RM review, it is still half the package.

content:
6, 2015
A worthy remake of the epic space opera that pioneered the three-dimensional strategy genreI remember playing the original Homeworld in 1999 and marvelling at the fidelity and amazing graphics. Launching the "Classic" version today – only possible thanks to Gearbox recompiling the original code to run on modern operating systems – isn't quite as impressive as it was back in the day. How fortunate then, that they have done a stellar (pardon the pun) job with the Remastered versions of the two main games in the series.The graphics are top notch, with some incredibly detailed textures, impressive explosions and beautiful galactic backdrops. Both games now run in the same engine, however I would highly recommend playing Homeworld Remastered before Homeworld 2 Remastered if you're aiming to experience both, since the latter has even better graphics and many more polygons. The new and improved interface (used in both Remastered versions) also gets slightly more cluttered in the sequel, so you might appreciate the easier learning curve of beginning with the first game.Maneuvering a battlefield that goes in all directions can be a bit confusing at times, even when you've memorized all the controls. Occasionally you may find yourself fully zoomed in on an asteroid when all you wanted to do was to check up on your harvesters. If this happens, remember that you can use the Pause button to freeze the action until you find your orientation again. By all means, remember to use the Pause button even when you're not doing close inspections of rocks since it can (and will) seriously help with giving orders in the midst of hundreds of spaceships trying to destroy eachother. Also, a paused battle looks absolutely stunning with all the missiles, ion beams and explosions quietly suspended in space.Storywise there are a lot of things going on, with both campaigns more or less revolving around the Kushan (player faction) homeworld, Hiigara. While there is a cutscene between every mission that give brief explanations of past and current events, and frequent mentions of (and interactions with) other factions during the campaign, one generally feels a bit disconnected from the universe. The Kushan certainly seem familiar with the the friendly and technologically advanced Bentusi from the start, but who are they anyway? What do they look like, and where do they come from? What do they want? Naturally, those who are interested will find out more on the internet, but players shouldn't expect the games to pique that interest.While certainly not without it's (minor) flaws, if you're into space, strategy and/or Adagio for Strings, the Homeworld series is well worth your time and money. Not just because it started a new genre, but more importantly because it is undoubtedly still the king of said genre.

												Frigate lost. Frigate lost. Frigate lost. Group one reports victory. Ooh, nostalgia! For me personally this is still one of the best RTS series out there. Still a great story. Still great gameplay. Still great voice acting. Still phenomenal sounddesign and music. Why still? Well, be advised: If you buy this remastered version it may happen that you run into some bugs. Minor ones (i.e. units are not correctly displayed while docked to the mothership) and major ones like the well known 'general failure' crash-to-desktop. The latter was fixed for me as gearbox stated in one of their news from february 2015 that it would be REQUIRED(!) to update to the latest ati/nvidia graphics drivers. Otherwise the game would not run stable. But, still...11/10.

content:
ry 25, 2015
												Since the vast majority of negative reviews here are misleading and either nitpick or make vague and uninformative complaints about failed launches, I figured I would give you guys a more comprehensive first impression of Homeworld Remastered. Before I start though, know that I haven't played the original Homeworlds and am new to the series. Also, the in-depth review will come a bit later, given that I've only played for a couple of hours. Here's a quick summary of the game's pro's and con's. Pros: + Satisfyingly simple yet beautiful visuals+ Ease of use [I was reticent about how easy it would be to control fleets given the scope of the game and my inability to micro efficiently but the controls are spot on].+ Audio---I can't stress this enough. Gearbox got the original developpers to contribute their original audio files—UNCOMPRESSED—for the remastered game. If you have headphones that are half decent or, ideally, have dolby 7.1, you're in for a treat. Also, the zoom level will give you access to different levels of audio. Zoomed out? You have the audio of high ranked officers and frigates. Zoomed in? You hear the dogfighting grunt screaming for his life as he's blown up. + Story: The narrative does a good job at not holding your hand too much. It drew me right in during the first few missions, and combined with the audio and headache free controls, nothing is really in the way of you experiencing the story without any hassles. +Depth. Again, I can't stress this enough. Try to imagine a complicated hierarchy of ships and tiers, combine that with coordinated strikeforces which utilize altitude and formations, combined with a great two tier command system of macro and micro commands, and you get a fantastically intricate rts which flirts with becoming overwhelming but never quite gets there. Cons:- While the graphics are satisfying, there are certain elements that seem a little oldschool. While I know this was done to maintain the nostalgiac visuals of the original, you get some weird combination of amazing textures on the mothership with odd and clunky parts. - The learning curve. If you're not into strategy games or are looking for something to easily jump into, this might not be the game for you. It's not a simple point and click. Like I mentioned, you have a 3d plane of combat, so you have to worry about attacks from above and below, as well as front, back and side. Also, if you weren't really into space themed games, distinguishing a corvette from a frigate from a carrier will take some memorization. Honestly, forget these chumps who are using steam reviews as a support or troubleshooting forum. They don't post specs, probally haven't even attempted to take the most basic steps in fixing these problems, and are just firing off "Not Recommended" left and right. While I acknowledge that my experience, however seamless, won't be the same for others, I think that a certain level of patience is in order given that it's launch day. I've seen AAA titles have much more horrific launches than this gem of a game.A B-List gamers review. Check us out on the Curators page for similar reviews.

												It seems unfair to write a (negative) review with just a few hours spent, but the game simply doesn't impress me. This goes for the remastered versions, I haven't tried the classics yet.+ Beautiful. Nice settings, nice backgrounds, nice ships. All good.+ Sound/music. Some people might argue that there shouldn't be any explosions or sounds in space but...not me.+ User interface. Very easy to handle, gives you all the information you need. Very intuitive.+ Real 3D space battles. This is the one aspect that I still have a lot to learn of.+ There's a limited amount of resources on each map and you carry your surplus with you to the next mission.- Each battle feels like I just mass my ships and plunge them in there. No thrill, no excitement, no fun. Maybe I'm a natural at composing fleets that'll crush all opposition, but I don't know... The missions I've played so far has just been me waiting for my fleets to destroy the enemy and retreating damaged ships for repairs. And carrying tens of thousands of resources from each map means that I can build 2-3 new fleets if I should get my fleet wiped out.In conclusion, the game looks great and feels great but just doesn't give you a proper challenge. I would recommend the game if you are unfamiliar to the genre.

content:
6, 2015
A worthy remake of the epic space opera that pioneered the three-dimensional strategy genreI remember playing the original Homeworld in 1999 and marvelling at the fidelity and amazing graphics. Launching the "Classic" version today – only possible thanks to Gearbox recompiling the original code to run on modern operating systems – isn't quite as impressive as it was back in the day. How fortunate then, that they have done a stellar (pardon the pun) job with the Remastered versions of the two main games in the series.The graphics are top notch, with some incredibly detailed textures, impressive explosions and beautiful galactic backdrops. Both games now run in the same engine, however I would highly recommend playing Homeworld Remastered before Homeworld 2 Remastered if you're aiming to experience both, since the latter has even better graphics and many more polygons. The new and improved interface (used in both Remastered versions) also gets slightly more cluttered in the sequel, so you might appreciate the easier learning curve of beginning with the first game.Maneuvering a battlefield that goes in all directions can be a bit confusing at times, even when you've memorized all the controls. Occasionally you may find yourself fully zoomed in on an asteroid when all you wanted to do was to check up on your harvesters. If this happens, remember that you can use the Pause button to freeze the action until you find your orientation again. By all means, remember to use the Pause button even when you're not doing close inspections of rocks since it can (and will) seriously help with giving orders in the midst of hundreds of spaceships trying to destroy eachother. Also, a paused battle looks absolutely stunning with all the missiles, ion beams and explosions quietly suspended in space.Storywise there are a lot of things going on, with both campaigns more or less revolving around the Kushan (player faction) homeworld, Hiigara. While there is a cutscene between every mission that give brief explanations of past and current events, and frequent mentions of (and interactions with) other factions during the campaign, one generally feels a bit disconnected from the universe. The Kushan certainly seem familiar with the the friendly and technologically advanced Bentusi from the start, but who are they anyway? What do they look like, and where do they come from? What do they want? Naturally, those who are interested will find out more on the internet, but players shouldn't expect the games to pique that interest.While certainly not without it's (minor) flaws, if you're into space, strategy and/or Adagio for Strings, the Homeworld series is well worth your time and money. Not just because it started a new genre, but more importantly because it is undoubtedly still the king of said genre.

												Homeworld Remastered is genuinely a breath of fresh air in the RTS genre all over again. Gearbox have done a fantastic job of reviving this classic series of 3DRTS action, with a beta multiplayer to boot. At the time of writing this, the multiplayer needs severe balancing and bug fixing, but it shows great potential. All four races (kush, taiidan, hiigaran, vaygr) are now all available in the multiplayer, however the homeworld 1 races need the most adjustments.The remastered collection runs in the Homeworld 2 engine, with revamped graphics and the formations of homeworld 1 are now implemented into the game (however I don't think they function as gearbox intended, most likely will need fixing).The collection also comes with the classic editions of both games if you feel like a trip down nostalgia lane, or if you just want to see the difference between the original games and the remastered editions.If you enjoyed the original games, or have just come across this for the first time, I highly recommend purchasing it.

												Wow. What a delightful surprise. I played HW1 casually when I was a kid, but when I picked up this remaster as an adult, the graphics, voice acting, and soundtrack blew me away.Never have I played an RTS and experienced so much beauty that I just had to sit there and gawk at the screen for extended periods of time. I found myself locking the camera on fighters and rooting for them in massive battles. After a while, I felt like I was spending the night stargazing and admiring the beauty of the cosmos, not playing a video game. In a break in the action, I thought to myself, "I think I just had a spiritual experience in a video game..."

number of helpful: 16 of 32 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
ry 28, 2015
												For those who wanted to play Homeword 1 with a new coat of paint and maybe a some UI (User Interface) improvements, this ain't it. Instead what you get is a half ♥♥♥♥♥ mod of the Homeworld 1 capaign for Homeworld 2. Almost nothing works as expected. The UI looks awful, feels awful and is in most ways no improvement over the original one. There is a reason there was no Homeworld 3.The graphics look good. They did a fine job remodeling the ships. Unfortunately with none of the actual behavior modeled, the ships feel like empty husks. Turrets of corvettes don't seem to independently track and shoot enemy ships like they used to, and when big ships fire their giant cannons, there is no recoil on the turret. Everything feels like a 3d-Max model making pew pew sounds.Formations don't work. Instead of the giant walls of capital ships surrounded by spheres of corvettes and wings of fighters you get to choose between a few different amorphous blobs and any time the ships move or see an enemy, the blog disintegrates.Battles don't work. If you follow a fighter, you see that it couldn't hit a side of a mothership if it was docked inside it, making fights between fighters and corvettes take forever. On the other hand, assault frigates swat fighters out of the sky like so many flies. It's obvious Gearbox didn't even slightly try to match the balance of the original game.Salvaging enemy ships doesn't work. Or one could argue that in all their bugginess they work too well. Just make a few of these and capture the whole enemy fleet: fighters, corvettes, everything, and you are done. Just don't build any of your own ships because they will shoot at the captured ships. You see, Homeworld 2 had boarding frigates that captured the targeted ships in place, so the engine doesn't actually support salvage ships that take their prey back into the mothership, and it's obvious that Gearbox didn't want to make any actual changes to the engine, or do any testing.Homeworld 1 classic works. Too bad you don't get any graphical updates or UI features while playing it. Although, it's probably for the best since Gearbox doesn't seem to care about the things that made this classic great. Homeworld 1 is still a fantastic game and doesn't look nearly as dated as they make it look in their comparison videos. All they needed to do was these things:- Use the original physics and game simulation engine.- Update the 3d rendering engine to support modern resolutions and shadows. Although if that was too hard, updating just the models and textures would have been fine too.- Increase the simulation steps per second to at least 30.- Add time control.Instead of doing these things, they made some nice looking ship models for Homeworld 2. Hence the turd that is Homeworld Remastered.

content:
ry 26, 2015
												I am very pleased to get a working copy of HW on my system again and to play it at 4k UHD.  Unfortunetly, I have crashed a dozen times, had weird graphical glitches that resolved themselves with lowering graphical settings and restarting the client repeatedly and the story line missions are buggy as all get out.  MAKE SURE TO SAVE BEFORE JUMPING TO THE NEXT SYSTEM.  And saving between major events helps too.  If you restart a mission for whatever reason, or it crashed, using the auto-generated saves the mission often won't flag completion, you'll miss research and you will be very frustrated.All in all, the graphics are beautiful, controls intuitive, and the game nostolgic.  With all the bugs, this REMASTERing feels more like a visually pretty but unstable beta product.  They may fix the problems over time, but, I am quite dissappointed that my '99 experience of HW was more stable then this remake.*EDIT* On Mission 12 of HW1:RMI have reached a Can Not Continue bug where the mission objectives are not completing and the cloaked ships are not spawning.  HW1:RM is much too easy and not giving the same replability of Classic.  Lacking controls, UI, tactics and difficulty. Very disillusioned.HW2:RM feels much more integrated and even prettier then it was originally. I would suggest waiting for Steam Summer Sale and get HW:RM for 50%.  Hopefully they will have fixed the bugs, problems and multiplayer by then.

												Of the many games I have played over the years, this is one of those that stands out in my memories. Being a person that has little patience or time to complete games, I would normally use trainers to get through various sequences of a game to finish it as quickly as possible while absorbing the story. Not this one. It always had a certain 'spark' that kept me on the right path to follow it through to the very end. Few have done this for me.In my opinion, it deserved remastering and hats off to them - they stayed true to the original and gave it an incredible polish. The story, music, in-game interface, narration, graphics and attention to detail are as close to perfect that I can imagine.My only regret is not being able to purchase the collectors edition.

content:
ry 26, 2015
												Homeworld 2 absorbed my time for quite a while, and I regretted not having beat Homeworld 1, but the game was just too old and felt too clunky to hold my interest. So I bought this. Honestly this is hands down the best 'remaster' of any game I've ever played. It feels like it was developed this year, the visuals are crispy, the controls are improved as well as the interface.And this game has not changed. The story is still amazing. The music is still haunting. It will still kick your butt. This isn't your classic 'turtle and hoard' RTS. You're going to lose a few missions. You're going to have to adapt your strategies. In other words, its Real Time, clench your cheeks and make with the Strategy. I would recommend this to anyone who likes the genre, and to anyone looking to try the genre.

												I have put hundreds of hours into the original HW2 game, played it with every mod imaginable too. Before the remastered version was even heard of i was still happily playing it with friends. But i always had a thought in the back of my head that this game needed so much work just to be even playable on my rig. So so many crashes, so many bugs that made the game impossible to play, so many times i'd stop playing too out of frustration to then come back later after realizing their is no other game out there quite like homeworld 2.To finally be able to play HW2 without error, without issues arising every time i load a single player map, or unable to connect to a friend to compete against due to incompatibility issues. Its  finally all over. i now have to simply press a few buttons and am away with the ships in a far away galaxy.The remarstered game is everything that i personally hoped for. These bugs that people are complaining about i personally haven't seen and even if i did i wouldnt care because at the end of the day a game 15+ years old finally getting the love and dedication it deserves trounces all that. I could never play the first homeworld and right now i've just completed the first games campaign and it was amazing. if you never touched the game before you'll love it. Its a hefty price for a great game, but entirely justified. They truely remastered the franchise and i hope that any company in the future hoping to relaunch a franchise will look up to gearboxes great example. Gearbox managed to keep everything the Fans loved, fixed everything we hated and added everything we wanted. Bravo to the team who did this!!

content:
1, 2015
												(As of this writing I have only played Homeworld Remastered, not 2)I was a bit hesitant to purchase this due to the fear that these games weren't as great as I had remembered. I was relieved to find out that Homeworld holds up to the test of time and in this remastered version it looks better than ever.The one thing I remembered about Homeworld was the atmosphere which is enhanced ten fold thanks to the remastering. Nothing compares to sending in a large armada full of fighters, corvettes, ion frigates and destroyers against another force of equal measure and watching the battle play out. Fighters whip around in the void dodging fire and letting loose upon the opposition. Destroyers fire heavy volleys of missles and projectiles which crash into the enemy's ranks. Ships flame out and tumble into an explosion when destroyed or in the case of capital ships they spin around and emit a huge fireball complete with debris. When the battle seems lost you can order your remaining fighters to kamikaze in a last ditch attempt to save the mothership. The backdrops are incredibly beautiful and stunning to look at. This remastered edition makes the game look like I remember it looking.Now with all that being said there is a bit of jank. Scripting has a tendancy to break. Movement commands get a little fuddled sometimes. I have had a handful of weird audio bugs as well. The zooming in and out via the mousewheel is a bit weird considering the setting being in 3d space you would think you could just keep zooming out to move the field of view up but you can't. A small amount of other issues have me scratching my head sometimes.Taking all that into consideration Homeworld has always had a special place in my heart. This remastered edition has me skipping and jumping for joy down memory lane as I relive all those massive space battles I remembered having. If you have any reverance for these games buy this edition right now. If this is new to you I encourage giving it a shot. If you aren't hooked before the first two hours of play you can always get a refund through Steam but I am pretty confident if you like space, explosions and strategy you will find a place in your heart for Homeworld as well.

number of helpful: 8 of 16 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
6, 2015
												Homeworld is a space RTS game released in 1999, it gained popularity by not only creating the single most intuitive space strategy mechanic to date, but also had an amazing story line and one of the most beautiful music scores ever. In Homeworld and Homeworld 2, resource management is key, every resource you collect on one mission gets transferred to your next, so it is a good idea to use it wisely, often relying on salvage ships to steal enemy ships over building your own. Space combat is done on a fully 3D plane, where ships can easily move in all 3 axis, which at the time was revolutionary.Gearbox did an amazing job in remastering this great gem, the graphics is amazing, while keeping the story and the music intact the game is truly perfect now. They made some UI and control changes but in the end it results in a smoother gameplay.There are a few minor bugs such as a sound issue with ship engines when too many of them are moving at once, and the tutorial being slightly broken (you get asked to press okay to continue to the next segment but the tutorial continues on as if you already pressed it), however these are minor gripes and does nothing to ruin this wonderful title.My ratings are as follows:Graphics 8Music 10Story 10Gameplay 9

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
15, 2015
												Is it a cash grab? Most remasters, absolutely. This remaster, however, shows an incredible amount of care given to the resurrection of a timeless classic, an IP that still has a great deal of potential. In order to make such an incredibly faithful remastering, key artists from the original art team were hired to breath new life into the graphics and the original composer was brought in to touch up the soundtrack. As such, everything has been retouched with an incredible amount of care and respect. True, some mechanics have been changed across both games (the first one most of all). Purists will be disappointed to be missing out on some mechanics, such as strikecreaft fuel, and some missions will be changed somewhat as a result. However, I believe that those omissions that were made in the remastered editions were for the better, in order to create more consistent games over all. I haven't tried them yet, but if you really want the original experience all over again, the Classic versions are bundled along with the rest.Considering all of these things in addition to subtle improvements to the HUD in both games, full modding support, the addition of a steam-supported multiplayer, and even fleshed out options menus, I can say that Homeworld has been reborn and that it can very easily compete with many modern RTS games in terms of immersion, challenge, and depth. With any luck, this will be the jump start that the IP needs as a whole.... and now back to my fleet of salvage ships!

												alright, before I begin I want to point out that I played the originals a long time ago. So when This came out, I went on a nostalgia trip. But, I will try my best to be fair in this.First off, They have done an amazing job with the graphical updates. the game is beautiful. That's a very nice touch.At the end of it, I would definitely recommend this.-----------------Oh, I almost forgot. This has a launcher that allows you to play the classic version of both games. That is a seriously nice touch.

number of helpful: 38 of 77 people (49%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
ry 25, 2015
												I'm a diehard Homeworld fan, but this "Remastered" collection is very disappointing so far in playing my first several hours.  It is riddled with bugs, even more than the original (which is saying something).  Even with Gearbox saying they rewrote the engine, I see some extremely similar issues to the old game.  I can deal with minor change such as ship costs (and apparently Fuel is no longer a resource for Strike craft), and I'm still a fan of the plodding pace and solitary atmosphere, but the issues I'm going to talk about make the price tag of this remake painful to have forked over.  It's amazing this was released in this state and I'm having a hard time believing that much work really went into it.Here is my current laundry list after playing for about 7 hours today (release day):Hotkeys and information.  Some ships have "special attacks"; good luck finding out what those are or whether they exist, until you find the hotkey for it and try it.  There are no more detailed info panes for ships now, at least that I can find, so you have very limited info on anything's capabilities.  Also, this game causes some kind of interference with system hotkeys... including preventing my ability to use in-game Shadowplay, which is what I use for videos and streaming.  UI for units currently selected is very small, slow and klutzy.Queueing up multiple Research ship pieces will result in only one being built.Capturing and Salvaging problems.  Salvage Corvettes will fight over the same pieces, following each other around.  You cannot tell a group of them to capture a group of enemies either; you must pick them one at a time.  Friendly units will happily open fire on any unit you have in tow, even though it is on its way to the mothership to be assimilated and poses no threat.  Harvesters will also fight with them over carried salvage.  Salvage Corvettes or Harvesters carrying salvage will clump up and prevent each other from delivering anything to a Carrier or Mothership.  Likewise as above, you cannot target groups of salvage to gather with a group of ships; it must be one at a time, or waiting for Harvesters to try and do it on their own.  Finally, a personal gripe; why do they make it hard to distinguish what ships you own after capturing them?  At least they could have changed the color of the exhaust trails or something to make it easier to know what's happening in a battle.Pathfinding.  There are clipping issues and other bits of forgiveable things, but sometimes ships of any kind will lose their minds and do a dance in place until you figure out what direction they need to get free.  When you need groups of ships to engage combat quickly, sometimes they will spend 5-15 seconds trying to recover their formation before they'll engage.  Also, as with the original game, rarely (but comically, at least if you're not playing) a ship you ordered to move (whether part of a group or not) will decide to go off in some completely random direction and will not stop.  Ever.Asteroids.  Oh god, these are horrible... This was always a frustrating level, but now when destroying asteroids, they fade away for a moment, and then slowly create a few dangerous new ones that can't be shot at right away.  The biggest problem there is that you can't select these new ones to attack half the time; if you try, sometimes your idiot ships will just start driving straight into them.  Ships will do no defensive or proactive fire whatsoever against the asteroids.  To boot, when you start the mission, if your carrier ships are on Auto-launch, all your little brittle ships will line up in perfect parade order to get themselves killed.  Finally, when you lose the first dodge-the-asteroid mission, the screen fades to black, but the rest of the game keeps running.  No end screen or anything like that, and you can hear your actions on the keyboard still having effects.Drones.  These little morons will kamikaze into your own ships whenever you activate or deactivate them.  Oh by the way, how do you activate them, you say?  Must be a button or something convenient, right?  Nope:  It's Ctrl-Shift-D.  And you'd never know unless you went through the game options for the key bindings.  I also had issues getting a group of Drone Frigates to respond to this command when deactivating; I often had to do it for each one individually.Repairing.  Pathfinding issues aside, it doesn't appear any Repair Corvettes or Frigates will repair some corvettes that you've captured from the enemy, at least some of the time.  Groups of repair ships will also have the same arguing issues between themselves as Salvage Corvette/Harvesters when trying to patch up the same ship.I'm going to keep playing it to get my money's worth, but I'm afraid I can't recommend this remake at all, as compared to just going out there and getting free or almost-free copies of the original games.  The graphics are much prettier but they aren't mind-blowing for 15 years of progress, and certainly not worth this price.  I'll probably find more issues as I go along, but I'll try to stay optimistic.

number of helpful: 15 of 31 people (48%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
ry 26, 2015
												The "remastered" part is well done. Graphics, UI and all that, but I do not remember this many obvious bugs in the old Homeworld.- My research vessel for example is completly invulnerable. I just had 30 enemy fighters and a Heavy Cruiser (!) firing at it and it just kept repairing itself at about 40% health.- Then there is this shrieking sound that seems to come from Corvette and Frigate class ships. It stays even if you move away. Pausing and continueing the game is a workarround.- Captured Taiidan carriers are somehow unable to build anything. Capturing them is semi-useless that way.- Captured ships seem to play the lottery when it comes to their paintjobs. Some stay in Taiidan-yellow while others shine in Kushan-grey. (Edit: I even got one with pink stripes. YMCA-Cruiser!)And this is just Homeworld 1 to about half the missions. None of it is totally gamebreaking, like CTDs or crashes, but it shows a rather unpolished release.Gearbox also couldn't keep their hands off changing things. For example, Fighters don't require fuel anymore, making the Khadesh fuel ships obsolete. While the reasoning behind this is debateable (probably for HW 1&2 multiplayer compatibility), they were somehow unable to fix lacks in the user commands, for example letting Repair Corvettes guard a group of Salvage Corvettes so that they pick targets to repair automatically. This was okay 15 years ago, but today it feels really really annoying to have to micromanagement everything yourself instead of enjoying the broader strategy game in a true three-dimensional environment.Edit: Okay, now that I played through Homeworld 1 I can only say I'm shocked. This is a typical Gearbox game. The beginning is alright and due to the story events epic, but after about half the game it becomes a static "move there and jump". Its like the enemy AI is turned off. At the end I had 7 Heavy Cruisers, not of them built, and also 12 Destroyers. And guess what, the Taiidan rebels gifted me two more, like it wasn't easy enough yet.It was said the enemy fleet scales with what the player has, so I was hoping for an epic battle at the end. What I got was 3 enemy Heavy Cruisers. You can guess how epic that was.Another AI shutdown happend at the giant hyperspace inhibitor 2 missions before the finale. There are three jumpgates which you are supposed to destroy, because they'd send reinforcements otherwise. Thing is, there are no reinforcements, EXCEPT when you go for the gates. But then you are already there to destroy whatever comes through. If you leave the gates in peace, you can do your thing without the AI trying to stop you.This was the easiest RTS I've ever played in 20 years since Dune 2, simply because the AI does absolutly nothing. Combined with the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ annoying sound bug, Homeworld Remastered 1 is a complete waste of time!

content:
20, 2015
												Much has been written about the improved graphics in the game. The screenshots speak for themselves. But, unfortunately, apart from enchanced graphics there are few positive moments to notice.The in-game speech seems to be recorded anew. I liked Makaan's voice. Fleet Command and Cpt. Soban are good, too. Karan is a bit… not like herself. But you won't probably notice that. Planet Killers theme from the last HW2 mission I've been anticipating the most is just absent. All the other aspects of sound and music are ok.Cutscenes are renedered in 1080p and look just awesome. But the in-game video player is implemented poorly: horrifying lags are obvious, while Media Player Classic plays the same smoothly even at x4 speed, let alone at normal.That is all for the good part. Now the bad part.First, despite nice textures, all the animations and VFx are left as it was. No new interesting additions (such as docking bays holding grip of resource collectors while unloading resource units or a destroyer losing a part of hull being heavily damaged). The repair beams and welding flashes stay as they were, while the soul craves for something more spectacular and immersive. Some of capital ships just don't fit the Mothership docking bay, going through textures. The Junkyard Dog turns ships in space as if they were made of near-weightless thin indestructible cardboard!. Hiigaran miners dock "through" Vaygr refineries, piercing the solid metal with antennas. Damage model is exactly as it was in Homeworld 2 — weird and unimpressive. And so on. Nothing positive has been done here since the Classics.Procedure of taking a "clean" screenshot is spectacular. To do that, you must manually disable all the HUD elements and deselect all ships, and having taken a screenshot set everything back as it was. All in all, nearly 10 key presses are necesarry to make a screenshot.As the game is about playing, not watching, and the Homeworld series is a thrilling experience to play through, in 20-30 minutes you will completely forget about graphics and concentrate all efforts and attention on gameplay.Hotkeys map seems to remain at the initial state. Most keystrokes are 2 or 3 keys combinations, scattered all over the keyboard without pretty much structuring. Learning and using those is a piano challenge. Nothing has been done to improve the keyboard controls.The campaign felt hopelessly easy. Closer to the end of the game (each one) the resource pool grows to 6-digit magnitude. That causes "why don't I build a full fleet of these and try them on something hopelessly well defended" thoughts. The overall state of the campaing indicates that by the time of release no one of the developers had taken a notepad and made a full playthrough of the campaign, marking bugs. When the junkyard Dog at Karos snatches a ship, you are supposed to lose contact with it, but you do not. The ships are supposed to be disabled after that, but sometimes they are not. Sometimes the Dog just tries to place the second ship to where the first is located, thus getting stuck. The Karos Proximity sensors Net is composed of freshly-painted sensors with Hiigaran insignia on them.... I have spotted a swarm of such mistakes during the playthrough.Enemy AI can make a grown man cry. No cooperation between ships is observed, and any signs of intellectual activity within the enemy ranks seem absent. Sending frigates wave after wave into the same minefield is just an example of a typical AI routine. The multiplayer AI seemed a bit better to me. In campaign there is none.Ship behavior is untouched (or even wasted a little). Single corvettes are ineffective (due to special placement of their turrets). That concerns all other ship types as well, so the ships with high coverage ratio are the most powerful ones.  Optimal attack patterns or any means to assign them manually are absent: a bomber can grind a resource collector just standing in one place, but instead it will move at max speed, and on the second run won't shot a single round because of asteroids blocking the shot. So, fighters and corvettes are a pity to watch at (especially single ones, with no squads and poor coverage). Whenever a ship escapes to safety through Hyperspace, rest assured: all your forces will target the enemy base to avenge the humiliation. Repair corvettes and minelayers will go in the lead, as the most agressive and eager to fight. The Gehenna border outpost will be as tough a target for a bomber aqs before: the start of the attack run is a fixed radius, the end is hear the enemy hull. So, the length of the run is negligible here and no real damage will be done. And that is instead of standing and grinding the target. There are worse things. Sometimes resource collectors just get stuck in place cutely blinking the engines instead of mining. Sometimes one of the ships boosts to 4000 speed or so and goes darting to the enemy lines or making enormous circles. My opponent once said his collecors are stuck inside one another and unable to move. Sometimes two corvettes try to repair each other, so they can't dock and go waltzing up to the uppermost boung of the map.  Gravitation Wells do not affect Vaygr corvettes, and Assault fighters had the kamikaze damage compared to a full-sized frigate each (has been corrected on 05-03-2015)The user interface. The only thing I did not expect of it is to get this much worse. The largest button on the screen is "Menu" — the button to be used 5-10 times in total. The next one in size toggles sensor view and is never used, as it is bound to the Space key (which is extremely convenient). Right under it is an enormous control group panel that does nothing. Fleet build queue reacts poorly (especially the pause button) and takes 3 keystrokes to open (3 more whenever a build-capable ship is built or lost). The lower right corner is occupied by never-used basic action commands, such as Attack or Move.  Everything listed above and to be listed below is to be scaled manually: extremely small on dtfault and clumsy and self-intersected on larger scales. Build and Research queues provide as few useful information as possible, and have to be scrolled due to the command panel below. Selection and commands do not work near UI objects, selection mechanism is suboptimal, so in combat situations the UI is bound to fail you constantly. Building 50 fighters take 50 clicks. 50 more whenever you change your mind. Overall element placement inUI and credits sequence indicate it has probably been done by a secondary school boy in exchange for a day off school. There is (maybe was corrected on 19-03-2015) a place where one of the names was covered with the white frame around a picture. I haven't even started a talk about possible improvements of the original: robust and fast probe deployment, fast access to compact build options, advanced formation and beharior tweaks (must be implemented in "real life", not only on the GUI.Balancing factions is a great work. Great work yet to be done, as the task seems untouched by the developers. This task is in tight relations with ship behavior, so I don't even know where to start. Stealth figters are worth a special mention: being the most advanced Kushan tech, they have less DPS than a scout, move slower, can't hit smaller targets at all, and can't do real damage to larger ones. With feaures this outstanding they should be permanently cloaked without decloak on attack.SUMMARY: to be straight and honest — this is an alpha. Totally raw; loads of aspects haven't received due attention. Multiplayer platform is good and priceless for seasoned players. Textures and models are great. Everything else has been neglected with or spoiled. And it is not the graphics what makes a really good game.
