number of helpful: 6 of 13 people (46%) found this review helpful
content:
2, 2016
												As I have never played the original Homeworld series before, my comments made here are based on my feelings playing this game as a new player, and not on whether this is a good remake of the original series.In this game, basically what the player needs to do is pretty much like all the other RTS games, such as harvesting the resource, creating a fleet, researching new technology, defending the mothership, and destroying all enemy spaceships, etc.The differences between this game and other RTS games include:1) There is only one type of resource in this game. It's simple but quite boring.2) The battlefield is in the outer space; there is no topographic features of any kind in this game. That is, no roads, no lakes, no mountains, no nothing to speed up or slow down the moving speed of your units. Futhermore, you can't hide behind anything to dodge fire; you can't plan ambush; and you can't make a detour or anything. You just go directly toward the enemy then fight, and so is the enemy. 3) When you assign multiple units in a fleet, you can specify its formation. However, there is no tutorial or hints to tell you what are the advantages and disadvantages of each formation. In fact, after several hours of play, I still have no idea at all whether the selection of formation will affect the attacking or defending ability of the fleet or not.4) Although the player can command a specfic unit to attack a selected enemy, normally you won't have time to do so, as you cannot pause the game and there are simply too many enemy to target and you got so many spaceships to control. As a matter of fact, the program always hung up whenever I continuously move my units around the map. I'm not sure whether it's the problem of my computer (which I bought around a year ago to perform some computationally intensive numerical simulation) or there actually is a bug in this program. As a result, all I did in this game was to produce spaceships, group them as a fleet, assign them to attack, then they will move straightforward to the enemy to kill or get killed.5) The strength of your enemy in each mission is scaled to match the strength of your army at the end of previous mission. You are triumphant to have won a tremendous victory in a mission? You probably won't laugh for long because in the next mission a much stronger enemy is waiting to greet you. 6) The research is boring too. There is no such thing as tech tree in this game. Basically you just click on the research tab whenever the game tells you that there is a new tech available for you to research. And in maybe 30 seconds, the system informs you that the research is completed, and then, you are done. Oh, I almost forget to mention that they didn't even bother to design the icons for the technologies. It's just a text box; you click on the box whenever the system reminds you to do new research.Of course there are some nice features that enable the game to have received an overwhelmingly good review from the players. However, if I were to know those game settings/features as listed above, I would not waste my time or money on this remastered game.

												FULL OF BUGS and Original Homeworld 1 Gameplay mechanics removed. WAIT FOR THEM TO FIX IT BEFORE YOU BUY IT !!!Both of these things turn what should be a beautiful remaster into a frustrating game.List of bugs in order of appearance:Level 1 - Game camera Went BLACK permanently after a cutscene. I had to restart the level. (This was like 4 minutes into the game, seriously Gearbox have you never heard of BETA TESTING !!!)- 2nd Resource collector I built dissappeared on level 1 after I sent it to harvest some resources. THERE ARE NO ENEMIES ON THAT LEVEL !!!- When the game asks you to stop a Turnanic Carrier from escaping, I destroyed it promptly and it said MISSION FAILED and the Hyperspace button appeared to complete the mission but I could only use the restart the mission button....- Encounter with Bentusi to trade. Bentusi ship and Mothership have a Star Trek esque standoff right in front of each other. This blocks your Mothership from undocking Capital class vessels from its 'side door', so had the mobile resource unit I just built stuck for about 10 minutes.- Support ships fail to dock with resource collectors resulting in a very bizzare dance of the 2 ships which left both ships blown up on the Radiation field level.- Black Camera AGAIN !!!! when you're on the edge of the Homeworld system to destroy a hyperspace inhibitor. Yet another Mission restart.I haven't even completed the game yet but I believe that this prompt review/WARNING was warranted.This severe lack of bug testing tells me that the game was hurried into release, whereas all other assets point to what should be an amazing remake. The Retextures and new graphics look spectacular and really do look amazing.This game needs some serious patching and even more bug testing.

number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
2, 2015
												Homeworld. It used to be considered one of best RTS's ever made set in space combat. After it was remastered it still is one of best RTS's ever created. I have never played original games, bought the game during recent steam sale. Money well spent. The game is just amazing. Homeworld 1 Remastered feels like one is playing Battlestar Galactica (2003-2009). On the other hand Homeworld 2 Remastered is more of war story while keeping up mysticism of 1st game.First thing I can tell you now the game is not easy, You need to learn its controls and how it works otherwise you will keep loosing. When you learn ropes of the game its extremely pleasant to play and most importantly enemy will still outnumber you, i.e. in 2nd game the enemy will have 10 battlecruisers while you have a cap allowing you to build 2 bc's. Quite unfair considering their firepower but frigates are perfect cannon fodder for that :PStory of two games is just amazing, both cause you feel rush and despair. Graphics in comparison to original game imporved really well fitting modern standards (including 4k if u can handle it). The soundtrack is purely amazing and is used in appropriate moments to affect us as players when necessary. Adagio for Strings choral by Samuel Barber is actually one of most beautiful songs ever created in our history. Yes, its used in best moments in the Homeworld 1 Remastered! Other soundtrack is also amazing but this very specific song is purest masterpiece of all, Gameplay. It's great. Cant say anything more. Combat is balanced, fights are challanging and its easy to loose if you're not using the thing in ur head at all. This is defiently not casual game where you hop in and immediately become a god in it (like designers of modern games do nowadays with games is just wrong!) Nothing beats sight of full scale fleet vs fleet combat. Bloody yet stunning.Homeworld Remastered Collection is great offer. You get 4 games (2 original + 2 remastered games) and if you are considering to buy it, do not hesitate. You will not regret spending your money on the game (sale or normally). Right now I feel like a thief for buying on summer sale. This game is worth way more than I've paid for it. I feel like I want to keep returning to the game to play it over and over. It is that good, great replayability value and satisfaction from it.To sum things up:+ Nicely improved graphics that fits modern standards+ Masterpiece soundtrack (and im quite hard to impress with music)+ Great Gameplay and replayability value+ Great story that actually makes you feel desperate, in rush+ Want more!+ Not casual...- ... which for some console peasants will be a bad thing.- some bugs - not well explained graphic settings in the video settings

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
1, 2015
												Experience so far with HW1:R     1. Played tutorial to brush up on game. Computer would proceed to next step without me hitting the proceed button. Fixed that by enabling subtitles. Oddly, received achievement for finishing HW2:R tutorials.     2. Had to restart mission 3 three times as my salvage frigates were on enemy fighter but would not bring it back to mothership. If I would not already own and have played the originals, would never have known this was a mission advancement bug.     3. Destroyed enemy carrier at end of mission 4, game went to mission failed, yet computer was telling me I completed it and the hyperspace button was showing behind the mission failed window. Did entire mission again and it worked.     4. Stopped playing at this point, as I didn't want to waste time playing and hitting another mission advancement bug. Will definately keep going, but knowing that is a possibility is a turn off.     Is it fun? Yes. Does it look good? Yes. Does it(and by that I mean HW1:R) feel like it wasn't fully tested and rushed? Yes.      I bought two copies. One for me and one for my son. We both had same issues on two different computers.      Should you buy? Up to you. I got my codes off Amazon for less than Steam's preorder pricing, after release, and after I read great reviews. Would I buy again? Knowing what I know now, I would wait for it to go on sale. But that's just me. Hopefully they will fix the bugs.     That being said, as I said before, it IS fun, but knowing I might hit an advancement bug ruins some of that enjoyment. Graphic bugs, etc., I can accept, but not something that keeps the game from moving forward.     Edit: Finished mission 5 without a glitch, although it seems much easier than the original. Just basically spammed and sent ships out to the enemy. No real tactics involved other than that.

content:
y 31, 2016
												There is a single reason i cannot reccomend this game. Dynamic difficulty. What is that? You have ships of total power 5, the next encounter has enemy ships of 7 power. You have total power 7? The encounter will be of power 9. You have 10 power? You go against enemy power 13. And so on. You always deal with a supreme force. A fleet equal to yours and somewhat better to counter the human brain superiority against CPU AI.The main supportive idea behind that is that you cannot focus on build a massive fleet and win by numbers. You have to use 'real strategy' and 'real tactics' to win. At least that is what they majority of fans are saying.Well i disagree. And the reason is simple. Firstly, i beat the game and without any save-load-try again stuff. Not a big deal, most players can do, if not they need some retries and that is all. Really, since when load and retry is a deep strategy and tactic?!?! On top of that, why build a lot of ships? The game does not count your stored resources for adjusting difficulty. You go with few ships, face few ships, build a few more and keep going. If that is strategy and tactic i am Napoleon.Not to mention the salvage corvette thing. Two corvette class ships can disable and salvage a frigate (and larger classes) but 2 combet class corvettes cannot take down a frigate. The salvage class ships would make sence if they salvage disabled or heavy damaged ships. This looks like a cheat to me and not a tactic.To make a long story short, do not build many ships, have 2-4-6 and so on salvage corvs, build few ships after the encounter has spawned and you are good for the entire game. Do not use your resources to build ships in advance before you hyperspace. 'To be prepared' obviously is not this game's motto. 'Play dead' is more like it.Nice experience from a view, i do not rememeber any other RTS punishing the hard prepared folks.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 25, 2015
												I've been a huge RTS fan for the longest time, since I was but a mere child. I played Empire Earth, Age of Empires, Sins of a Solar Empire, the original Starcraft and, last but not least, Homeworld 1 & 2 and Cataclysm. I adore these types of games. I live, breathe these types of games, but recently there has been such a drought of RTS games, except the phenomenal Grey Goo. But here, here we have it; the pinnicale of the past; one of the greatest games remastered and available on a digital platform. I can only exclaim, YES.Now, that my rant is over. I wanna name a few of my favorite aspects of Homeworld. Firstly, the music is to die for. It's glorious, epic, space ambient music with new age singing overlapping. As a huge fan of music, but mostly of metal, I can say this OST rivals many classics. The visuals are another strong point, there's something to be said about a game that can make spaceships docking into a hull fun to look at and experience, and the awesome "focus" feature which allows you to zoom in to see battles close up. The style/aesthetic is another fantastic point, sci-fi RTS games are rare but this one is easily one of the best. Most of all, though, I love the story. The story is a breathtaking space opera of epic proportions, it offers questions and makes an imagination run wild, it makes you sad and unkempt, but picks you right back up more hopeful than ever. It's a rollercoaster.This version isn't complete yet, though, since bugs are rather rampant. I hope Gearbox takes heed and fixes 'em but be warned, this game still has some problems/glitches. I will omit this paragraph as soon as these are fixed.That said, BRB, gonna relive my childhood.

content:
er 30, 2015
												I bought this when it was in the Autumn sale, hoping for a better, more up-to-date experience than the original. Both the remastered and original versions are included. The graphics are indeed very good but then it goes downhill... The audio (music) is very similar but some of the voices have been altered - I prefer the originals. On my original PC this pushed the limits performance-wise so I was pleased when I could now push everything up to 11 - and it all worked well (only occasional crashes). But what has utterly ruined it is the interface. It's clunky, some of the key combinations dont work when they are supposed to, the key bindings have changed from the original game - and some of them cant be re-assigned. Coupled with the lack of *Military (the default) ship formation for setting up squadrons, this makes it sooo hard to play and keep track of everything. I gave up after a couple of hours and got my money back (thanks to the Steam refund policy).I'f you've never played Homeworld you may like it and you would accept it as it is, not knowing any better. Unfortunately if you remember the original as fondly as I do then you are likely to be dissapointed.*You can get the Military formation by docking then re-launching all your ships immediately - but its a faff.

content:
er 25, 2015
												Seeing how this game's price has completely crashed during the Autumn sale, I figured I would add in my own two cents.My dad introduced me to the original Homeworld when I was about 7 years old. That was about 13 years ago, and even after playing every single spaceship-related game I could get my hands on, I never found anything which went into quite as much depth with story, lore and gameplay as Homeworld. Now believe me I was just as hyped as the next person when Homeworld: Remastered was announced - in fact my dad would tell you I nearly brought the ceiling down with my enthusiasm, especially when I discovered that it was Gearbox, well-known for producing the Borderlands series (which I am also a HUGE fan of) was in charge of spearheading the project and bringing it to us. When it came out I didn't really see much of the shtick it got for myself, but after taking more time to play it since I have unearthed its little issues that the original game lacks. The good thing about this though is that you get the original games bundled with the remastered versions, so if the Remastered versions' issues become a bit much for you, you can easily revert to them to take a break. Now I'll give a breakdown of my own personal pros and cons, make of them what you will!PROS - - The game is, of course, remastered - graphically speaking, the game is stunning - the lighting is perfection, the backgrounds of matches are perfect, and the various ships look beautiful with their new models - the frigates even have moving turrets, which I think was lacking in the original game. There is not a single flaw in the graphical side of the remastering, at least in my opinion.- The campaigns for both games have remained pretty much untouched - but a new GUI allows for easier interaction with the game world and better control over what comes into your mothership and what leaves it. - The ship upgrade system located under the research section allows players to upgrade the stats of their various ships, including damage, defense, health and occasionally speed. They can also be used to teach some ships new abilities. In the campaign mode you are limited to when you get these upgrades however as many of them tie into the story in various ways.- The addition of mod support, although often shaky at times, does allow for the addition of custom races, ship logos, maps and I think even gameplay modes. Some of these mods can even be used in online play, which I think is fantastic. - While the original Homeworld soundtrack has been left untouched and rightly so, the Homeworld 2 soundtrack recieved a remastering which has drastically improved the sound of its music, which was in the original game something of a partial failure (Some of the songs sounded shoddy or rushed for example but these issues have been fixed in the remastered soundtrack).- The lore is extensive and beautiful for this game, but many people are often unaware of this without having access to the original Homeworld manual, which was a hand-me-down from my dad which I still read regularly. The details contained within the manual are available on the Homeworld wikia for those who are curious about learning the extensive background of this universe, as much of it isn't actually mentioned in-game or at least not in a way that some people would really understand or remember. CONS - - The original game didn't have any bugs or glitches that I can remember. This one has a great deal of them, however - simple things like unresponsive ships, the occasional crash and other silly things you could perhaps expect from a game, but still annoying due to how flawless the original felt. - Mods often deselect themselves and don't load after being used in-game for only one match. Sometimes mods don't work at all or crash the game, which is appearntly a very common occurrence.- The patches do help but often don't fix the really important issues, such as common issues with multiplayer and mods.- Some gameplay aspects that people really enjoyed were for some reason removed, such as the ability to Salvage (why they even bothered leaving the poor little Salvage Corvette in the game is beyond me, considering that in the main storyline of Homeworld 1 they are practically useless after the 3rd chapter now and just sit there collecting dust until destroyed by enemies) and also the need to refuel ships. While I actually think of this as a good thing, there have been complaints about it and I can imagine that for some people it must have taken some of the survivability element away from them. - Although I have no solid proof at this time, I've heard that there are serious issues with multiplayer on occasion. Multiplayer also allows you to play as any of the races from the two games, which in some cases could be a little unfair as the races from Homeworld 2 have packs of Interceptors rather than one Interceptor per construction (just an example, I know there are others too), as well as having better ships overall. Overall I'd say this game is worth its sale price, but maybe is only worth its true retail price to the hardcore fans who will appreciate it and can ignore its flaws indefinitely. Also another tip: If you are one of the owners of the original CD of the game which came with the soundtrack on CD, you don't need to buy the Homeworld 1 Remastered Soundtrack. It's literally the same music. If your CD is still around or in good condition, use that instead and save your money :P However the Homeworld 2 Remastered Soundtrack is different from the original as stated above and is very much worth the money in my opinion.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
r 8, 2015
												Homeworld is a very niche game. If you like space battles and want to see the absolute best there is on offer from any game to be frank, you'd want this game. The actual game itself here is a bit of a rough diamond. The gameplay involves a spherical map where you can move your ships in basically any direction up or down as well as in the horizontal plane, which in theory would open up tactics and such. In practice, its mostly a minor annoyance, for all it is technically impressive. It is tactically useless, for the most part. You could the vast scope of the map, particularly its height to hide, but hiding is never practical to be honest - unless you're gimping yourself against the AI and carefully setting it up,  you're not making a battlestar galactica style comeback if you get smashed early on. The gameplay boils down to who has the best fleet and the best target acquisition.  You select everything, and send it into the fray all at the same time and then click the enemy to death. The aesthetics are really down to your taste but personally I hate the design of the HW2 ships pretty much across the board while the Kushan in HW1 are in the same boat as looking awful (fighters look like flying ice cream tubs)  the Taidann look far more convincing and the only ships I really enjoy looking at. The NPC races in the campaign look pretty atmospheric and fitting as well. The HW1 campaign is in the vein of traditional RTS games, where there are some missions with some absurd challenge that you need to try multiple times, which is a double edged sword but I think generally it works. It makes the game more interesting and about learning rather than turtling and then sending the biggest possible fleet at something. If you want the best experience, I'd never reload a save, (but you will spend hours waiting for resources to collect or fleets to build) and the reason for this is that with the gimmicky missions there's generally a key lesson that you'll learn or figure out on the first go, so the second attempt is really easy. In one mission, you'll find your small craft will almost always get wiped out due to overwhelming firepower. The solution is to just dock them in your carrier/mothership. Units carry over between missions. In the original game, this meant that if you spent hours waiting to collect all resources before moving on, you'd have a significant advantage in the next mission. In remastered, you get all resources all over the map at the start of the next mission. There's a clear reason why Gearbox has made this change but it makes the last few levels ♥♥♥♥ easy.The last 2-3 missions stop being unique like this and essentially become move and attack fests where you move your death fleet across the map and slowly destroy everything. The enemy fleets don't scale well to your own superfleet that is carried between missions and just about the most challenging large fleet action is in one later mission  where you effectively have to leave a small force of  capital ships behind to defend your mothership from flankers while you win the mission.HW2's campaign is better designed such that a few of these problems are less significant or non-existent. The difficulty is more consistent throughout unlike in the first game where the difficulty is far worse at the beginning of the campaign. The story elements in both games aren't anything overwhelmingly special but are pretty decent and get the job done. In terms of the remastered elements, Gearbox didn't totally screw it up, but they did do a pretty ♥♥♥♥ poor job. If, like me, you have a fairly new AMD card with the latest drivers, you can't play either of the classic games as they will instantly CTD on launch. This issue has been around for several months and hasn't been fixed, and likely won't ever be fixed.  One graphical issue I've seen involves ships becoming completely see-through. This has been around since release and hasn't been fixed definitively, though there is a solution - its as overwhelming basic as changing the properties on the HW shortcut, so its pretty pathetic that its still around. In terms of campaign bugs, some missions or objectives fail to complete and particularly the infamous asteroid mission has artificial difficulty stemming from the stupidity of the pathfinding AI literally flying into rocks, and the long pause between being able to target split up asteroids. One of the main reasons you may want to get it is because of the brilliant mods made for classic that are being ported to remastered (though extremely slowly - none of the major ones have yet made the transition) that literally serve to make Homeworld a platform for simulating any space warfare universe imaginable. There's Freespace 2, Halo, BSG, Star Wars, Star Trek, even Wing Commander amongst other things. I'd say the game is still worth getting on sale, even despite all these faults. There is a net gain in enjoyment from playing this game, though be warned if you have an AMD card.  I'd give the game about a 7/10 on a scale where 5 is *the* average game, and not an "average game".

content:
ry 26, 2015
												I'm only a few hours in, but wow. I never played the originals, despite being 31 years old and owning an extensive collection of games in all genres. Somehow, this series completely passed me by. After two solid hours of playing the remastered version of the first game, I am in love. The UI and controls are intuitive and smart, and the game systems are rock solid. To anyone in my situation contemplating whether or not this is worth the money, I'd say go for it. What truly makes this stand out to me is that it feels like a space opera. The story has grabbed me right from the get-go, and the immersion is like nothing I've ever experienced before. What really does it, in my view, is that with each new mission/objective, you keep your fleet and resources throughout the campaign. I don't know of another RTS game which does this anywhere near as well. The game feels like a journey home, and reminds me of the (later) 2006 series, Battlestar Galactica. It's fantastically written, the soundtrack is incredible and the world feels gigantic.Probably the best <£30 game I have bought in years. Very, very highly recommended.

content:
er 23, 2015
												When I was a tiny child, all I could do was just play the original Homeworld, and I played it every day for hours on end. I finished the campaign maybe only twice, though. On account that I wasn't very good at strategy at the time. When I found out that they made a second game, I also quickly got that one, and played it just as much, although I was never able to finish it at the time. In time, I moved onto other games, and I have long since lost the disks for both of these games.Every once in a while, I would check up on the status of the IP for the Homeworld series and would always be disappointed when I saw that it was tossed between companies, never to have a third game in the series. However, once I found out that it ended up with Gearbox and that they were going to be doing a remaster, I was ecstatic. At the time, many people were upset with the fact that Gearbox, who don't have a very good reputation with games, ended up with the franchise. I found no reason to doubt how good it would be, though. They would have actually TRIED to ruin a legitimate remaster in order to make it bad.Once the game came out, I quickly pre-ordered, and discovered that it lived up to expectations. Some parts were lacking, including tactics and some balance issues with multiplayer (to be expected. it's still a beta!) but besides that, the rich story was all the same. It still holds the special place in my heart as my favorite game series ever, and I'm excited to see where Gearbox goes with this next (I'm so excited for Sands of Kharak.)tl;dr: This game is very good. Please buy it. It's truly a classic and its story is incredibly rich and I recommend it to everyone!

content:
ry 26, 2015
												This game is absolutely amazing. If this had released in 2015 for the first time and not as a remaster you wouldnt ever know. The graphics are amazing, better than sins for sure. Watching turrets independently target different enemies is an epic sight. As for strategy, there is a lot more flexibility than traditional ground based RTS's. For instance in a multiplayer battle I played today, I immediately constructed a mobile refinery, and placed it where my mothership was. Then I proceeded to fly my mother ship straight up way out of sight, and then flew it over my enemies base and built up a massive fleet above them. They wiped out my resource collecting spot but I had already pumped out several Heavy Cruisers and had plenty of RU's to spare. Thinking I was done they fought my teammates. I then sent about 100 fighters,25 corvettes, 2HC's, some destroyers, and my frigates away from my mother ship and then descended on them in order to hide the true position of my ship. I completely wiped out one of the players, but by this time I was the last alive on my team and they searched endlessly for my position. Well...turns out one of my resource collectors survived and decided to return to base from across the map and through enemy territory but I didnt notice it. It was at this time, thinking I was safely hidden, I went to get a drink. I came back to see the resource collector being followed by an enemy fighter squadron right to my mothership. Shortly thereafter 3 enemy battlecruisers hyperspaced in, right next to it and quickly ended my existence in a glorious flash of light...But it was awesome. Buy this game!

content:
2, 2015
What I liked:  3D space RTS ( no other game does this well or at all)  Captures the theme of space to a nice degree ( think 2001 space odyssey if it was a game)  The balance of the game ( advanced rock paper scissors style)  The soundtrack has some great relaxing tribal instrumental music  Your fleet carries from beginning to end(no other game does this, why haven't they it's so cool)What You Need to Know:  Played this when I was a kid( but this review is not biased because of nostalgia)  Game is very slow paced and story isn't strong at all ( big maps don't help this either)  No branching tech tree, just simple upgrades to new tech  Flanking is real in this game, 3D flanking bro  This game is so easy to understand, and isn't like a 4X stratergy game  All units have counters, it's not asymmetricMy Score:A+Paid: $14 HW 1 completed in:  11 hoursHW 2 completed in:  8 hoursGames similar:   Supreme Commander   Star Wars Empire at War Shallow Space Improvements and Changes in the sequel
 Game speed is way faster as units move faster  Squadrons are now used for anything smaller than a frigate ( makes game easier to manage, and more epic)  You use boarding ships to capture and some units gain abilities that gets rid of some ships  You get a villian now, but the mission designs to me are just kill everything on map, ( less unknown suprises )  Research and upgrading is improved with small upgrades every ship, instead of just tech upgrades to unlock new shipsI know the first game is very slow, if you don't like it. Just skip it and go to the second one. You don't want to miss the best space RTS do you

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 3, 2015
												As someone who has never played any of the original Homeworld games, I can't comment on the changes made and if they are bad or good. That said, this game is amazing! Stunning models and graphics, great story and cut-scenes, and easy to learn controls are just the tip of the iceberg.  The skirmish mode lets you play with huge fleets in large scale wars which is a blast. The great mods being uploaded to the Steam Workshop only enhance that experience.While some people, probably most of the veteran players, dislike that both games in the collection (HW1 and HW2) are built in the HW2 engine, as a newcomer to Homeworld, I felt it made the whole experience more intuitive.  The transition between the two games was easy as it all felt the same. Two seperate engines might has disrupted the flow as players who just got accustomed to HW1's engine would now have to figure out the small changes made in HW2 and force a change in their mindset.All in all, an amazing, amazing game. I highly recommend!Can't wait for Homeworld 3! :)

r 23, 2015
												Homeworld.This is a game I enjoyed a lot playing the game for the first time, the brilliance of the attack plan which included jumping straight into the enemy (a friend who has never let me forget this) every single ship I owned. This was immediately followed by "wait. Mayber that wasn't such a good idea" then "OOOPS" as I watched the Mothership blow to pieces.This was my first experience at Homeworld Two, which despite my poor tactical skills at the time ended up setting me on a road of playing that game to the point of obsession. Until windows 7 and the game became incompatible with my computer and with a developer which no longer existed, pretty muched ended it there.So what does Homeworld Remastered Edition offer apart from a game that actually runs on a computer that isn't running windows XP? Better graphics for one and a crisper UI. As well as the oportunity to play multi-player over steam. In terms of selling the game, very little will make a difference if you haven't play Homeworld before. But if you haven't played it before, a "meh" before moving on isn't doing it justice.Would it have been possible for me to write this review without mentioning my experience playing it: No, it has simply shaped to much of my playing style in other games that to not mention this would be wrong.

content:
ry 26, 2015
												I just spent the last six hours ( thought it was three ) playing this game.I say, they have recreated this game in probably the best way I think could ever be done.I played a lot of Homeworld, and none of it online.  I spent a lot of time in the campaign, and in botmatches.  I even tried playing with the modding for a bit.  It was amazing.And now we have this.Coming from only having played Homeworld Remastered, not 2, or the Classics, or the multiplayer, I can say it is... exactly how it was.It even played performance-wise the same way!  I have a 550 Ti, and this this thing managed to pull a reliable 30 fps through 80% of the game, but there was a bit of dip in combat, so it was just like old times on my crappy Celeron PC back in the ages.Now, the remastered version uses the Homeworld 2 engine, so if you only ever played Homeworld 1, you might be a little bit confused.  I think the changes to the engine are a nice touch.  I spent quite a lot of time admiring that all the ships look exactly the same, but just... better.  The small details are REALLY nice, and I haven't even begun to touch them yet.  I have to work tomorrow. ...maybe...For instance, when the Turanic Raiders are encountered, focus on one of corvettes' missiles. You'll see.Anyway, there's any number of tangents I can go on, but basically, this game lives up to the hype machine that was created for it.  I only got to mission 5, and I already don't reget buying this as a pre-order.  I wouldn't regret buying it again for a different computer at full price.  If you loved either Homeworld game, but especially both of them, buy this.It will not be a game you regret buying. I look forward to fragging some of you in multiplayer.  :)Cons:  Still no Cataclysm.

												Homeworld remastered is exactly that, the original homeworld with slightly improved wrapping. While this is generally a good thing and if you liked the originals (like I did, a lot) then buying this makes sense. You will get the same game with updated visuals and sounds.However there are some negatives, most of them are just missed opportunities, but they still count as negatives:- Models are extremely low poly for a 2015 game- objects (mostly ships) could be much more detailed - Textures look low res as well- effects look 5-6 year old at least (like engine glow as such)- voices are a bit more bland then the original, they seem more like script read than a person saying them.In general it is an improvement on the original for sure, but the original was revolutionary for its time, this is passable at best for 2015

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 26, 2015
												Rose tinted glasses is a risk with the 'golden oldies'. Homeworld was a fantastic game back in the day, and to get that out of the way immediately: It still is. So, I recommend the game. But it is worth knowing ahead of buying that it is not a perfect game. It looks like a 2015 game. The game doesn't play like it, though. The campaign has a great story, but it has an unforgiving side and as your fleet stays with you throughout the game, it can be punishing or require loading. In that regard it's quite 'oldschool'. That is not necessarily bad - or good - but is something you should be aware of. As for the multiplayer, there's some region limiting that can be worked around, but you don't get more epic space battles than multiplayer Homeworld. Nothing even compares. I note that a lot mention bugs. I haven't run into any, for what it's worth.

												Even after 16 years Homeworld remains the king of the RTS genre. Tactically complex, beautifully imagined, and now lovingly restored for modern systems, it has lost none of its charm or fire. The new textures, sounds, and effects are stunning and the gameplay holds up as if it was new this year. If you're a fan of games like Starcraft, Dawn of War, or Supreme Commander you owe it to yourself to play Homeworld. If you're a fan of Homeworld than the only reason you should be reading this is because you're waiting for the download to finish.

												What can I say? I first encountered the Homeworld Series back in 2006 when I was out in Boston for a month with nothing to do. Standing in "Comp-USA" I wondered if I could play what seemed like this ulimatly, beautiful game on my laptop that was even a few years behind on it's own.Luckily, it did fine with it.This started a game I played religiously as much as I could. The beautiful space-scapes, entrancing music, and full sound for it's time where amazing.Homeworld: Remastered Collection honors everything I loved about the game and brings it to the table with new, updated graphics and all in one glorious package. While I've only gotten a few hours in now since launch, all of it has been worth it so far. If my opinion changes I will update this review, but for now, I am happy, and I am greatful that I can finally play this amazing game once more.

ry 26, 2015
												Homewolrd was on of those games where you either loved it or hated it. From my personal experience with the game, I really love it, had to really drag myself away from it at 2am this morning to et some rest for work later today.The game being re-mastered has managed to keep is atmosphere and environment, the story really pulls you in. Multitasking and designating your squads to defend carriers as well sending other squads to deal with the enemy carriers while you continuously harvest more resources and research. There is so much going on.The ui is slightly different, personally I liked the old UI but this new UI all it takes is getting used to.The PVP part of the game is where I think it will really make or break the game for the future. Personally I like the hyperdrive element brings in so many strategies like a decoy attack to the front of an enemy base while your team mate hyperdrives behind the enemy base and nukes.This game is awesome, if your in to RTS even as a solo player I would defo recommended it, the skirmishes against the CPU can be quite fun as well if you don’t like PVP.

content:
ry 26, 2015
												Okay, there are some issues with bugs and random crashes for many, but not all. Let's get that out of the way. Does it make the game "broken"? No, but there ARE issues to be addressed by Gearbox.I won't go into the graphics, story etc. as many reviews have covered this. Let me instead look at the game's 'difficulty' for the new RTS gamer.If you do not strategise and plan in 3D, which was revolutionary at the time (and still is, to my mind) you're going to have a hard time. When I played the original on release in my early thirties I DID find some of the mssions HARD, but then I wasn't used to this type of RTS. The delight was in solving the strategy for myself and finally 'getting it'! I hadn't come across this since "X-Wing", which really was a mix of simulator anbd puzzle solving (take out X bombers to pretect Hospital Ship - if you don't in a certain order you fail).So, it all comes down to planning and working out exactly what you need for each mission. "Tank Rushing" just will not work, and those with the biggest and baddest fleet, that takes sometimes far too much time and resources, will see you fail time and again (except in skirmish - which we didn't have back then).This game(s) requires thought, and aside from it's beauty (the original still looks marvellous), the strategy required is compelling. You'll hit your keyboard and close the game down in frustration sometimes, but your mind will keep churning over strategies until you come back and try again (and you will)."Brilliant and innovative" barely describes this title even today.

												10/10 for updated sound and graphics, 1/10 for trying to remake Homeworld missions on the Homeworld 2 engine (which was used for this remaster). You know, the one specifically written for this game. The one that brought a tear to my eye everytime I managed to beat the final mission, with pieces of plastic piercing the skin around my knuckles from repeatedly punching the keyboard in fury. Those were the times, man.As for the HW2 campaing, it plays out just fine, so eat that sh!t up because it's still awesome and on top of that, it looks like a million bucks.

content:
1, 2015
												One of my favorite strategy games of ALL TIME!!This franchise and me go back a ways...i was a younger teen when Homeworld came out and I had to have it!  The game was the first of its kind. at least it was for me anyways...Unfortunately the consoles started to show their faces, and I was taken from pc to consoles.It would be years before I would buy a pc again and I bought a laptop. Good thing im a game horder, because I still had my copy of Homeworld. Got back into the game and relived soo many memories.....and soon I would stumble upon Homeworld 2...."What?" I had no idea that there was a sequel....as I said it had been years....so I magicaly found a copy online and man was this a even BETTER experiance than the original!....Alas...It would be short lived as my laptop would die, and I found myself once more sucked into the next console generation.....As fate would have it...some more years would go by and this new next gen of consoles would be emerging...and I would not be suckered by this so called "NEW NEXT GEN"...So I went and got myself a high end gaming pc....the bad news is that I would not be able to enjoy my Homeworld games any more....well not to the extent that they once did...as the game did not support higher res grapgics that are out now.But GearBox has done something special by REMASTERING a MASTERPIECE! and once again I can enjoy this amazing franchise once more!!Well done GearBox!...there was alot of bad hype that this company was recieving. But this was done right in soo many ways!Thank you,10/10!!!

content:
1, 2015
												It's a remastering of two old games, so there are limits to what you can expect. Saying that the old games in question are classics so the having access to them again on new hardware was worth the cost from my point of view.The update also comes with improved graphics so the 3d models now look great at 2560x1400 on a 27" monitor, much in the same way that I remember how goood the originals looked at 1280x1024 on a 21" monitor. If you have played the original games (and can still remember back that far) you are looking at around 30 hours of game play to complete the included missions. beyond that there are PvC skirmish modes and a PvP system in beta.

content:
1, 2015
												Just finished the Remastered Homeworld and it was a great experience.However there is some things to be aware of:There is only the one dificulty level so when you have finished the campaign I don't see much reason to replay it.The fleet is preserved during the campaign this means that some of the later levels become too easy beacuse your fleet is too good or the level is impossible because your fleet is too small...I had to restart the campaign because I just barely  made one level to be totally crushed in the next. However after the restart I steamrolled the later leves.The space view sometimes turns black for unknown reasons and it's impossible to do anything, if this happens save and reload and the view is back.If MSI Afterburner is running there are lots of graphical glitches so don't.The game crashed once and lvl 6 didn't have any objectives once so it was impossible to finish the map (worked after restart of map) but other than that I think the game was pretty solid.Oh and the Junkyard dog stopped stealing my ships after a while I don't know if this was a glitch or by design.

content:
27, 2016
												I didn't like this as much as I thought I would.  I never played the original version, so I'm just now experiencing Homeworld in the Remastered Collection.It does seem to be a good 3D RTS engine and watching the ships in combat is amazing.  The storyline and plot is also interesting, at least as far as I played.  Is probably a game worth looking into or trying at least once, if its on sale.  But I think in today's RTS world, its a bit behind, even with the updated graphics.  I stopped playing at about the 6th mission for several reasons:1.  Even playing normal difficulty, the AI is brutal throwing in larger ships like Frigates and even Destroyers very soon in the game, I think about the 4th or 5th mission.  Before you have even had a chance to build more than a few of them.  So unless you have researched and crank out some serious frigates, you will be toast.  I think its the I've read some walkthroughs and you can "cheese" your way through these missions by capturing with salvage frigates, but that seems cheesy and more like an exploit, then winning with combat. 2.  Resources are limited and always seem to be on the same place in the map,  A group of asteroids or a cloud of interstellar gas - always in about the same places.   it makes it kind of boring and also makes the game a bit unforgiving, if you mess up and lose to many ships or make a mistake, the campaign mission is pretty much over, or the next campaign mission will be impossible because you don't have enough resources to build new ships or do research.3.  I got bored with the space theme.  It looks beautiful flying around for a while and watching ship combat, but then after a bit its boring to me, compared to land based RTS games.  In the land based ones, you can use the terrain to your advantage in attacking and setting up bases, and building defenses.  But in Homeworld, you are pretty much thrown into a system with your unmovable base ship stuck in one place.  With tons of empty space around you.  I just found that the combat got kind of boring because its mostly scrambling around to send groups of ships to certain places, without much strategy or base defense building involved.

content:
8, 2015
												I was born in 1990. When the original Homeworld came out, I was too young to understand or appreciate what this game was. I felt compelled to write this review after completing the remastered edition. This game is a masterpiece. An enrapturing odyssey encapsulating a simple yet beautiful story, a haunting score and thoughtful, refined gameplay. From the first mission of the campaign, I found myself entranced by a narrative that transcended any need for painstakingly rendered cutscenes or lengthy dialogue. Homeworld is an illustrative example of what creativity in the RTS genre is capable of achieving - in both storytelling and interactive components. On the cusp of the new milennium, Relic created a game which was so far beyond its time that it feels cutting edge more than 15 years after its initial release (obviously subject to graphical updates). Watching beams of light slice through a stunning galactic backdrop as huge fleets engage each other is an unparalleled experience. This game is a perfect 10.

content:
ry 25, 2015
												Oh my god.  Homeworld's back.  I never thought I'd see this day.  I don't know how many hours I put into the originals.So far, not many bugs on release other than a couple crashes.  If you crash, lower the texture quality a notch.  Even at 2048 texture size, it's beautifulTo top it off, this is NOT one of those games that looks better through nostalgia glasses.  Between all the engine improvements, HD textures, etc, it's BETTER.I remember playing HW1 when I was a kid and getting destroyed.  15 years later, with an adult mind, it feels like a different game.  I know how to manage resources better, I know the strengths and weaknesses of ships better, and try to organize my fleet instead of throwing units against the enemy hoping to get a kill.EVEN IF YOU DON'T LIKE RTS, GIVE THIS GAME A TRY.  It looks like another overcomplicated space RTS, but it's really not.  It's complicated in its own ways, but very easy to learn the basic tactics and rock-paper-scissor mechanics between all the different ships.This isn't like other RTSs.  It's very easy to pick up and play, hard to master against real players, but the selling point is the beautiful campaigns of HW1 and 2.  Not to mention the massive battles, with fighters zipping everywhere with their glowing contrails, and massive capital ships hammering at each other with cannons and ion beems.Good lord, it's been a long time.  It's more beautiful than I remember; with the Remastered engine, it's more than just a polished up HW2 engine.  Check out any comparison videos.This game has gotten *BETTER* with time.  How many series/remakes can say that?

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 25, 2015
												Just to start i must stat that im a huge fan of the homeworld series (owning all 3 big box editions of the original games in all their glory) when i found out about this i preorderd the special edition.To start the game is beautiful with new stunning skins, great new sound effects, cleaned up audio for the voice acting and wonderful draw cutscenes, not to mention the easier to use UI of homeworld 2 that makes homeworld 1 singleplayer that much easier and fun to play. These games hold their own on gameplay alone (dont believe me?, try the classic editions bundled into the collection!) but the remaster really does make the places you play in that much more special. The multiplayer (against bots for the moment) is also fun, being able to use any of the 4 major races across both games is really intreasting and gives alot more replayability.Its not all good news tho as this games does have bugs, so far iv noticed certain ships clipping through each other, ships not dissappearing after hyperdrive, the overview map not working at times, and crashes to name a few. However i still recommend this game as it is, with gearbox supporting modding for this game and a huge modding community already around, as well as possibility of (decent!) DLC and bug fixes, its a bright intergalactic future for Homeworld.

If you watch all the videos on the developers, you can see that they really are keen to keep this game going and fix all the bugs, so get off there backs and give them time to fix things. Rewriting code and troubleshooting is not easy most of the time. For the amount of time they\ve spent on this, which is surpising little. It's amazing!

content:
4, 2015
												When i saw this series for the first time, it caught my eye. why? it was the sheer beauty of it. and im not even talking about the remastered version, or the graphics of the games, remastered or not. it was the concept, the story, and the level of pure thought that goes into every moment of gameplay. The story is a classic tale of an odyssey across the stars to find your one true home, and along the way you meet friends, and monsters. You find those who have simply strayed from their paths, and those who want nothing more to see you burn. you must use your 3 dimensional battlefield to your advantage, and plot every move, for one slip up can cost you your fleet. The game is very well put together overall, and the originals are well preserved, the remastered ones however are not entirely true to the classic versions. In some instances you face more enemies than in the original, or Certain events do not occur at the right time or in the right spot. these are minor changes at best, but a sound strategy that worked in the classics, may not work in the remastered ones. Older fans will not be dissapointed, and new fans will hardly notice the difference. Despite these gripes i have to say it is still one of the best strategy games i have ever played, and certainly my favorite.

ry 27, 2015
												AWESOME USING NVIDIA ... I had the older Homeworld 2 ... the remastered is lots better ... however .. it is graphical intense really utilizing everythingy your Nvidia has ... but . it worth it as u will see if u get the game .. if u r uisng Nividia u could get also an error on first use ... it will lock and freeze ... do NOT worry ... no problem .... it is NOT the game nor your Nvidia card .. its in the settings .... the error will say OPEN GL HAS LOST CONNECTON WITH YOUR GRAPHICS CARD ... this is only for Nividia ... here is how to fix that ... the problem is .. it is looking for a time out to load the graphics ... as I said it is graphic intense but worth it ... to fix it ... all u do is on your main computer screen open the Nvidia Control Panel ... in the main Control Panel for GLOBAL ... if u look u will more than likely see that you have set yout GLOBAL SETTING OF POWER MANAGEMENT MODE to ADAPTIVE ... all u do is change your GLOBAL setting to PREFER MAXIMUM PERFORMANCE ... and wham bam ... all solved and u can play all u want .. what this does is open your Nvidia to use every resource it has for awesome graphics ... and believe me ... u will luv it .. if u do NOT set it to Perfer Max Performance u mite crash and burn ... I luv this game and give it awesome stars ! ... now go ... find your homeworld ... and have fun ... its totally Awesome ! ... GET IT TODAY ! ..

content:
ry 26, 2015
												Updated:  Make sure to read the bottom edit.The countless hours I spent on this series as a youngster were some of my fondest memories of gaming. I completed the campaign for Homeworld at least 3 times, HW2 twice, and Cataclysm (somewhat non-canon, but still good) a few times as well. I've only reached the fifth mission in this HW1 Remastered campaign, but it appears Gearbox did the series proud. It's beautiful without compromising the original art, the updated interface is mostly an improvement (I'm not crazy about the different hotkeys) and the sound updates are amazing. There are nuances to the sounds that I never picked up in all the time I used to play the game.One change that had me absolutely giddy is that it's now (much more) possible for salvage frigates to capture Turanic Raider ships. I always wanted a fleet of Missile Corvettes, and now it's possible to nab them all!Overall, I'm blown away by this remaster. I'm overjoyed at how well it's done. If you never played the Homeworld games and you're an RTS or space fan, do yourself a favor and play this game, now.Edit: There are some serious issues with the game that I hope will be fixed soon. These are:1) Harvesting resources in HW1R is buggy, and requires babysitting and constantly reassigning the harvesters. They will stop harvesting, even when there are additional resources 30 seconds away.2) Strike Craft Formations and Tactics are useless and broken: Moving HW1 content to the HW2 engine clearly broke these, and they are critical to making strike craft useful. As they are right now, you will constantly lose all your strike craft due to the unit AI's inability to utilize tactics and formations. It forces you to just boat captured Assault Frigate swarms and other Frigate/Capital ships instead. This is a major and disappointing issue, and possibly the worst of the list.3) The projectile system was dropped in favor of the "dice roll" system of HW2. This was one of the coolest parts of HW1, and was amazing to watch in action. Projectiles were actually fired and could hit targets on the other side of the target by accident. This led to strike craft being much more useful, as they could dodge rounds coming towards them, allowing them to overwhelm large capital ships. Now, Heavy Cruisers, Destroyers and Assault Frigates wipe out dozens of fighters without breaking a sweat. The best anti-everything weapon is just a mass of capital ships, in all circumstances. Forget attack bombers and defenders. The only reason to builds scouts and interceptors is as a cheap meat shield or disposable scouting element.4) Time to Kill is INSANE. INSANE. Take two heavy cruisers or destroyers, and have them start shooting at each other. They die in like 30 seconds. It used to take twice that long, turning capital ship fights into epic slugging matches. Now, it's all just one giant, stupid deathball.5) Scaled difficulty is broken: Just collect a few dozen ships, and by mission 10, you'll see what I mean. If you're familiar with the original HW, you'll see that they have more than quadrupled the number of enemy ships guarding the ghost ship. It's hilarious and game breaking.I really hope they fix these issues, as HW is one of my favorite franchises, ever. It pains me to say this, but HW1R is not worth playing until most of the bugs get fixed. I haven't played HW2R enough to see, but I'm sure it's fine as it's in the same engine. If you want to play HW1, stick to the classic version. I pray it doesn't have the same issues.

												+ Breathtaking story and atmosphere (music and voiceacting take a great part in this)+ Better graphics / sound+ Still works on older machines (My notebook is 4Y old and I can max out almost every setting)+ Almost 1:1 to the original+ New UI is imo much better in terms of usefulness+ Voice acting is very good, also for the new lines+ Cutscenes are beautiful+ Auto collect at the end of a mission (thank you so much!)Small minuses:- UI (...) is good but not perfect. I miss my list of ships and list of enemy ships in sight. It's much harder to see what you're up against compared to the original.- Well even tho I love how they tried to change as little as possible I would have been very happy if they implemented one or two more comfort functions from the other games. Namely: An option to 8x game speed (HW Cataclysm)Some issues that might (hopefully) get fixed:- Support fregates have to move very close to a larger ship (i.e. destroyer) for repairs. Sometimes the ships circle around each other and the support fregate isn't able to "dock" until the repair target is destroyed. This makes them completely useless in combat for everything above corvettes. Most of my ships died before the fregates could get in position. In the original they flew behind the ships and it was no problem.Edit: After a few missions I completely quit to build them. Useless and extremely frustrating.- Formations don't work. Not even if the ships are idle. Thats not a wall!- Same goes for the tactics. Example: Ships will often attack enemies that are being salvaged. That also happens sometimes even if tactics is set on Passive and you give a movement order in the opposite direction- Harvesters randomly idle even if there are still resources left (extremely irritating)- AI is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ as hell, also your ships often move or realign in the most ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ way possible.It's critic on a high niveau. Still a very good game with a few flaws that will make you tear your hairs out.

ry 28, 2015
												Disclosure, im did play both Homeworlds' back when they were released so i cant rule out any nostalgiacolouring my opinions. However with that in mind i do think they honestly made the best remastering of anold game that i've seen even rumoured to date anywhere.It stays true to the original with changes being obvious ones like strike craft refuels gone (Fellas theres a reason it did not make the cut in HW2). The original HW UI has indeed been replaced with a slightly improved HW2 UI for the original aswell which is a great damned thing indeed.Graphics wise, its incredibly well done. Consistent style and very wide range of options to tune it so it'll stay fresh for quite a number of years. (Yes you can actually get it to hog up any but the mightiest GPU's if you do a big fleet battle)Even more striking in my opinion is the audio rework since the originals had some quite hefty restrictions on their fidelity based on the technology on most PC's back then.Absolutely a must buy for any serious RTS and Sci-fi fans. Though i suspect folks fond of todays hyperactive RTS(RTT really) genre might not cope with it well what with you requiring to actually devise stratagems instead of just micromanaging and outexpanding your opponent.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 28, 2015
												The game that defined space RTS, remastered in glorious HD. I cannot express with words what this game evokes in me, pure joy and pleasure of once again guiding a people across a vast galaxy to defeat a foe that is far superior in every way.This is a game that any RTS and/or space junkie should play in his lifetime, not because it looks good and runs superb on practically any modern PC. But because the story and narrative of the game is so well written and executed that by the end of the game you feel connected to it, to the characters and to the ships you've commanded. The remastering done is simply put amazing, both the visual quality, sound fidelity and atmosphere is superb. Detailed ships, nebulas, asteroid belts and clusters of light all basked in the beautiful galactic background - SPACE.The mechanics of the original game are intact, all the clever ways to manipulate the outcome of battles is there. The balance of things has been brought in-line and the type of units matter. The mechanics are much clearer when it comes to unit types, don't expect a flurry of ion cannot frigates to easily defeat a destroyer or heavy cruiser, likewise assault frigates do big damage to slower moving corvettes and struggle with fast interceptors. The utility units are now really useful in big fights and a gravitywell generator and a cloak generator do wonders to turn the battle, especially if you are being bombarded by fighters and corvettes. Capital ships perform as they should, massive firepower and generally low speed, they will decimate every frigate and likewise because of their heavy armor are much harder to kill by frigates.As of this writing the game is at v1.2, the only problems that I've encountered are minor AI bugs. Specifically resource collectors will not automatically harvest resources if their nearest asteroid/cloud is out of range they just stop and you have to re-issue the harvest command. Ships sometimes fail to follow/guard another ship, they simple stop and you have to either re-issue the guard command or manually move them nearby. There have been a few slowdowns where the mouse and map freeze for a few secs, but those were no more than 5 in the whole campaign.Generally none of the above bugs affect the actual gameplay and you can be certain that they are not game breaking.

												The beautiful thing about Homeworld is that the original game, before being remastered, aged extremely well.  I played through it (the unremastered version) earlier this year actually and it was very hard to believe that the game was 15 years old.  So given that it now looks absolutely stunning, it feels very, very modern.  In terms of quality, this game (in my opinion) would easily worth a lot more than it's current price tag if it was a new game releasing for the first time.  So if you haven't played Homeworld before and are wondering if it's still worth playing now,  I'd highly recommend you go ahead and pick this up because this is a game that has survived the test of time and plays just as well today as it did back when it first released.  It is not one of those remastered releases where the gameplay mechanics aged badly despite some pretty new textures.For those of you who are already fans of the original Homeworld and are just reading these reviews to find out if this remastered version is worth picking up, the answer is yes.  You can rest easy knowing they didn't break the game or try to change it or somehow ruin it doing something stupid, it  feels, and plays exactly like the original game, and visually, it maintains the original look and feel so well that despite having far more advanced visuals than the original, in a sense it looks exactly how our nostalgic brains probably think we "remember" the first looking, back when it's visuals blew us away oh so long ago.

content:
1, 2015
												It is with both sadness and joy I think back on the bankruptcy of THQ. On the one hand it meant Metro passed from competent hands into the unknown abyss, but at the same time the Homeworld franchise got hit by the defib.  Relic and Sierra both pretty much went bust after Homeworld 2. The title was sold then sold again and that was it. Stuck in economical limbo by a company that did not want to touch it with a five foot stick and rightly so, because how to tackle such a game without creating another Colonial Marines?But it was revived, by Gearbox of all people, and again hope felt lost. Perhaps it is still lost, but this remastered edition of the original masterpieces shows competence from a company mainly associated with cellshaded gore. There's some funky voiceacting in some places, and you can tell sometimes which voicerecordings are old and which are new, but never has the Mothership looked better.I know there's a lot of people who complain about broken mechanics, such as formations, but I have had no such issues. 15 hours to move through the main campaign at my own speed and not a single gamebreaking issue has surfaced. No broken combat mechanics, no broken triggers, both HW 1 and 2 formations work for me. There are some graphical highjinxes though, such as commandeered taiidani ships randomly changing colours between missions, but nothing eyesore-noteworthy was had. Whatever issues people may have with random crashes it hasn't happened to me. Homeworld was a near flawless experience when it was released, one of the absolutely best strategy games ever made. What this remastered edition brings though is so much more than just a higher available resolution and support for inherent 64-bit systems. The graphics are now current generation level. Same with the sound and the classic cinematic sequences. To get that kind of update is like turning Quake into Crysis 3. The difference IS that big. Another great addition is the remade UI, the greatest improvement over the old HW 1 system. And of course let us not forget the updated multiplayer with quite a fair amount of new mechanics to spice things up. I would say it's not just a remastered edition of the original games, but this is exactly what should be expected from a remastered edition. This is what a remastered edition of any game should actually do. It's not just a relabel of the game; it's what would be expected of an RTS title released today. But then again, this is Homeworld. It was already a real-time strategy diamond and credit to Gearbox for all the hard work that went into this. They know what they're doing. They WANT this to be every bit as good as it can be, and it shows.

content:
ber 15, 2015
												To put it simply - Homeworld literally revolutionized the RTS genre when it was first released over 15 years ago. I bought the original game and throughout the years, it was always a deep regret that this great game was not available on Steam for everyone else to discover... until now! This remastered version is not just putting the original game on the Steam store - every part of the game has been improved and updated, surpassing all expectations for such a classic reborn. This digital collection is a great opportunity to experience what made Homeworld such an enduring game. The amazing fanbase which has kept this game alive all these years finally prompted the original developers to update and release it on Steam. If you are a fan of the Star Wars movies or gigantic space battles with epic scenery, this is definitely something that you should check out. Homeworld is quite different and special compared to other RTS games - it has an original outlook on space combat with a game engine capitalizing on the beauty of combat in space, which has never been as successfully captured in any other games. The game is so beautiful that you could make movies from the gameplay footage if you wanted - in fact, there are several fan-made movies out there with Star Wars or Battlestar Galactica mods, simulating the original look of the various ships in their respective franchise.The story and sound effects are very immersive, contributing to a chilling cinematic atmostphere where you can feel the loneliness of your civilization lost in space as you build your fleet while preparing for explorations and enemy encounters. The learning curve is easy compared to other strategy games so feel free to give it a try. It's worth it!

content:
ry 25, 2015
												My partner received this game and has played it thoroughly, but she did not get a chance to finish it.  I can tell you, for a fact, that she loved the original game and was overjoyed when she had the opportunity to play this.The graphics are superb, and she loved every minute that she played of it.  Here is the review that she asked me to copy for the game.Pros:  The graphics- the graphics will melt your eyeballs directly into your head.  The brightness of the sun as it pans into your viewscreen would turn any vampire into dust immediately.  They are THAT realistic.Gameplay- Combat happens quickly, and it cannot be paused.  You can restart any time that you wish from a quick saved game, but who wants to do that?  Death and destruction is part of the galaxy, folks, and you will see plenty of it.Audio- Your neighbors will insist that the Apocolypse has arrived, centered in your living room.  Even at the lowest volume, if you have downstairs neighbors then they will be pounding on their ceiling for you to turn it down.  The explosions rattled my teeth and killed my pet skunk.  Not before he sprayed his gunk everywhere, though.Battlefield size- The best game that I ever played that comes close to this is Sins of a Solar Empire.  If you've played that, imagine each battlefield to be as large as an ultra large galaxy map in its entirety.  Battlefields are in true 4D space, and combat happens from up, down, sideways, behind you, diagonally, etc.  TRUE 4D.  The only way it could be better would be if you could actually feel the heat from the explosions, but then your couch would be melted and you would be dead.  I suppose we should stick with 4D.Cons: Length.  Too short.  I spent (as many hours as it showed I played) and didn't even come close to finishing it, but I knew how many missions there were.  I made it to (check my achievement history) before I couldn't play anymore, and it is the high point of my last half year.  Knowing that the end of the game was coming mad me sad, and I wanted to cry.  Then why did I say it's too short?  Because it will come to an end, eventually.  I wholeheartedly endorse this game, and this is the largest review that I've ever written for any game in my library.  That means a lot.************************That ends her review, and I agree.  I watched her play, and was mesmerized by the storyline and the action.  I never played the game before, so it was all new to me.  This game is not going to be a waste of your time or money, I promise.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 25, 2015
												Oh my god.  Homeworld's back.  I never thought I'd see this day.  I don't know how many hours I put into the originals.So far, not many bugs on release other than a couple crashes.  If you crash, lower the texture quality a notch.  Even at 2048 texture size, it's beautifulTo top it off, this is NOT one of those games that looks better through nostalgia glasses.  Between all the engine improvements, HD textures, etc, it's BETTER.I remember playing HW1 when I was a kid and getting destroyed.  15 years later, with an adult mind, it feels like a different game.  I know how to manage resources better, I know the strengths and weaknesses of ships better, and try to organize my fleet instead of throwing units against the enemy hoping to get a kill.EVEN IF YOU DON'T LIKE RTS, GIVE THIS GAME A TRY.  It looks like another overcomplicated space RTS, but it's really not.  It's complicated in its own ways, but very easy to learn the basic tactics and rock-paper-scissor mechanics between all the different ships.This isn't like other RTSs.  It's very easy to pick up and play, hard to master against real players, but the selling point is the beautiful campaigns of HW1 and 2.  Not to mention the massive battles, with fighters zipping everywhere with their glowing contrails, and massive capital ships hammering at each other with cannons and ion beems.Good lord, it's been a long time.  It's more beautiful than I remember; with the Remastered engine, it's more than just a polished up HW2 engine.  Check out any comparison videos.This game has gotten *BETTER* with time.  How many series/remakes can say that?
